university-resources/ohio-state-history/.title: McMillin Observatory
university-resources/ohio-state-history/.description:
In 1896 on a hill overlooking what would become Mirror Lake, Ohio State's first astronomical observatory was build. It was named the McMillin Observatory after the New York banker who funded the project. He also provided the funds to beautify the area around the observatory, including Mirror Lake. At the time, the university had been considering laying a road through Mirror Lake, which was nothing more than a collection of interconnected bogs fed by an underground stream. \

(McMillin Observatory, 1897)
university-resources/ohio-state-history/.author: Millie
university-resources/ohio-state-history/.sourcePath: University Resources/Ohio State History/McMillin Observatory.md

university-resources/ohio-state-history/.title: Mirror Lake
university-resources/ohio-state-history/.description:
Photo Courtesy of Ohio State:
Mirror Lake Islands Party (1878):
Mirror Lake with Visitors:
Mirror Lake Grotto: Was the first contact and not a person. A 'horiculture wagon' was pushed into the lake as a Halloween prank. "With the exception of running the caissons over the campus and dumping the Horticulture wagon in the lake, the students were as quiet as could be," The Lantern read on November 6th, 1895. "To guard against trouble the street car authorities had heavy guards at the end of the Neil avenue line and on High street near the University. They were entirely unnecessary, no trouble whatever occurring."
Mirror Lake Islands: First reference of freshmen being thrown into the lake. Front-page cartoon in 1909 depicting freshmen in the middle of the lake, dubbed the 'Freshman Bathtub'
Mirror Lake Islands:
Tug-of-war between freshmen and sophomores across the lake and Bucket and Dipper members being initiated by being thrown into the lake.
Mirror Lake Photographer and Seven Kids (1911): Mirror Lake Bridge (Two Men on Bridge) (1915): Windstorm Damage (1918): Snow Scene: But 1920 is when it seems the tradition became more serious with approval from student council and the university president. The rules: Freshmen must wear a specific cap at all times and not step foot on the Long Walk, the brick path across the Oval leading up to Thompson Library. Only assigned enforcers, members of the Bucket and Dipper club, were allowed to toss freshmen into the lake. 1922, the Lantern reported members of Bucket and Dipper would even defend freshmen from being dunked in the lake by those who were not permitted to do so, i.e. non-Bucket Dipper members. "Bucket and Dipper announces that no promiscuous 'ducking' or 'dipping' is to take place under the auspices of other organizations. Any attempt to haze freshmen in this manner by other organizations will result in Bucket and Dipper's strong-arm squad defending the freshmen." The student council rejected alternatives to the dunking in Mirror Lake put forth by faculty members. 1922 was the last tug-of-war across Mirror Lake. University president said, "The University is trying to make the lake a place of as much beauty as possible." 1926: Freshmen got fed up with dunking into Mirror Lake and planned an event to burn the hats they were forced to wear. A huge fight ensued and police were called to the scene. Sophomore was hospitalized. 1929: "For all practical purposes, freshmen rules are already a thing of the past. Although several attempts have been made to revive the freshmen taboos, and particularly the cap-wearing tradition, the rules have been virtually non-existent since Bucket and Dipper was shorn of its power to enforce them." Mirror Lake Fountain (1931): 1942: Tug-of-war made another appearance for tradition week and stuck around for May week in following years. Ariel View (1947): Mirror Lake (1950s): Last known reference of tug-of-war across the lake. In 1955, references to dunking popped back up in a Lantern editorial with the following reasons given for dunking: honorary initiates, fraternity seniors, pinned or engaged couples and any other willing soul. Mirror Lake facing North East (1961): 1964: An engaged couple 'quarreled' at the lake; the man took back the engagement ring and threw it in the lake, and the woman went searching for it in a bikini. She was arrested but the executive dean finally allowed her to resume the search in different attire. 1967: Last reference of Bucket and Dipper initiating members by dunking them in Mirror Lake. Man sitting in front of tree without leaves: Fountain and Path, Bike Rider:
university-resources/ohio-state-history/.author: Millie
university-resources/ohio-state-history/.sourcePath: University Resources/Ohio State History/Mirror Lake.md

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: Control Charts
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description: Comparison of univariate and multivariate control data Control charts are used to routinely monitor quality. Depending on the number of process characteristics to be monitored, there are two basic types of control charts. The first, referred to as a univariate control chart, is a graphical display (chart) of one quality characteristic. The second, referred to as a multivariate control chart, is a graphical display of a statistic that summarizes or represents more than one quality characteristic. Characteristics of control charts If a single quality characteristic has been measured or computed from a sample, the control chart shows the value of the quality characteristic versus the sample number or versus time. In general, the chart contains a center line that represents the mean value for the in-control process. Two other horizontal lines, called the upper control limit (UCL) and the lower control limit (LCL), are also shown on the chart. These control limits are chosen so that almost all of the data points will fall within these limits as long as the process remains in-control. The figure below illustrates this. Why control charts "work" The control limits as pictured in the graph might be 0.001 probability limits. If so, and if chance causes alone were present, the probability of a point falling above the upper limit would be one out of a thousand, and similarly, a point falling below the lower limit would be one out of a thousand. We would be searching for an assignable cause if a point would fall outside these limits. Where we put these limits will determine the risk of undertaking such a search when in reality there is no assignable cause for variation. Since two out of a thousand is a very small risk, the 0.001 limits may be said to give practical assurances that, if a point falls outside these limits, the variation was caused be an assignable cause. It must be noted that two out of one thousand is a purely arbitrary number. There is no reason why it could not have been set to one out a hundred or even larger. The decision would depend on the amount of risk the management of the quality control program is willing to take. In general (in the world of quality control) it is customary to use limits that approximate the 0.002 standard. Letting X denote the value of a process characteristic, if the system of chance causes generates a variation in X that follows the normal distribution, the 0.001 probability limits will be very close to the 3σ limits. From normal tables we glean that the 3σ in one direction is 0.00135, or in both directions 0.0027. For normal distributions, therefore, the 3σ limits are the practical equivalent of 0.001 probability limits. Plus or minus "3 sigma" limits are typical In the U.S., whether X is normally distributed or not, it is an acceptable practice to base the control limits upon a multiple of the standard deviation. Usually this multiple is 3 and thus the limits are called 3-sigma limits. This term is used whether the standard deviation is the universe or population parameter, or some estimate thereof, or simply a "standard value" for control chart purposes. It should be inferred from the context what standard deviation is involved. (Note that in the U.K., statisticians generally prefer to adhere to probability limits.) If the underlying distribution is skewed, say in the positive direction, the 3-sigma limit will fall short of the upper 0.001 limit, while the lower 3-sigma limit will fall below the 0.001 limit. This situation means that the risk of looking for assignable causes of positive variation when none exists will be greater than one out of a thousand. But the risk of searching for an assignable cause of negative variation, when none exists, will be reduced. The net result, however, will be an increase in the risk of a chance variation beyond the control limits. How much this risk will be increased will depend on the degree of skewness. If variation in quality follows a Poisson distribution, for example, for which np = 0.8, the risk of exceeding the upper limit by chance would be raised by the use of 3-sigma limits from 0.001 to 0.009 and the lower limit reduces from 0.001 to 0. For a Poisson distribution the mean and variance both equal np. Hence the upper 3-sigma limit is 0.8 + 3 sqrt(0.8) = 3.48 and the lower limit is 0 (here sqrt denotes "square root"). For np = 0.8 the probability of getting more than 3 successes is 0.009. Strategies for dealing with out-of-control findings If a data point falls outside the control limits, we assume that the process is probably out of control and that an investigation is warranted to find and eliminate the cause or causes. Does this mean that when all points fall within the limits, the process is in control? Not necessarily. If the plot looks non-random, that is, if the points exhibit some form of systematic behavior, there is still something wrong. For example, if the first 25 of 30 points fall above the center line and the last 5 fall below the center line, we would wish to know why this is so. Statistical methods to detect sequences or nonrandom patterns can be applied to the interpretation of control charts. To be sure, "in control" implies that all points are between the control limits and they form a random pattern.

Advantages and Disadvantages of Measures of Central Tendency Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> drag VOI(s) into the 'Variable(s)' screen Under statistics, you can choose from a wide variety of statistics. You can also create the frequency distribution figures we discussed previous weeks under the Charts menu Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Descriptives -> drag VOI(s) into the 'Variable(s)' screen. Under Options, you have the ability to choose from a slightly less wide variety of statistics. Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore -> drag VOI(s) into the 'Dependent List' screen Under Statistics, choose 'Descriptives' You don't have the ability to choose what descriptive statistics you want, but this menu gives you almost all 'Descriptives' Under Plots, you can also produce box-plot, histogram, and stem-and-leaf plot You can get descriptive information based on different groups in your dataset. Drag any categorical variables you are interested in into the Factor List box. This will produce separate charts and figures for each of the values in the variable you place in Factor List Means Analyze -> Compare Means and Proportions -> Means and Proportions -> Means -> drag dependent variable into the 'Dependent List' box Under Options, select the descriptive statistics you're interested in. You can also use this menu without comparing groups Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> .... Both variables x and y are interval and/or ratio level variables (scale variables) Population correlation is denoted by p (rho) Sample correlation is denoted by r: -1 < r < 1 -1.00: a perfect negative relationship 0: No linear relationship +1.00: A perfect positive relationship Characteristics of Correlations: Direction: Positive Negative Strength: The actual number calculated Can be any number from -1 to +1 A high correlation does not imply that one variable is causing the other; it simply means that these two variables are related in some fashion. Correlation does not imply causation. Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Simple Scatterplot' into the preview box -> drag one VOI to the x-axis and one VOI to the y-axis. Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Scatterplot Matrix' into the preview box -> drag all VOI to Scatter matrix box Analyze -> Correlate -> Bivariate -> drag VOIs into 'Variables' box Under 'Correlation Coefficients' select which type of correlation you want (Pearson) Under 'Test of Significance' select which type of test you want, based on your hypothesis. Steps: Double click your table Click 'Pivot Controls' Drag 'Statistics' into the 'layer' box Select Pearson Correlation Covariance Shared variance among x and y. Correlation is simply the standardized covariance.

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 4. Normality
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
When we assume normality, we assume the distribution of sample means is normal. Look for extreme departures from normality. Checking for Normal Distribution Looking for extreme departures from normality. Skewness: A measure of symmetry (lack of symmetry) Type of Skewness: Positive Skew Mode < Median < Mean Negative Skew Mode > Median > Mean Distributions with medium kurtosis (medium tails) are mesokurtic. Distributions with low kurtosis (thin tails) are platykurtic. Distributions with high kurtosis (fat tails) are leptokurtic. Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore Skewness Ratio: Skewness ÷ Standard Error Kurtosis Ratio: Kurtosis ÷ Standard Error If these values are between -2 and 2, we are good. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> Move the variables of interest into the variable box -> click 'Charts' -> select 'Histograms' and click 'Show normal curve on histogram' If data points fall along the straight line, the data appears to be normally distributed. If the data points considerably deviate from the line, the data appears NOT be normally distributed. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore -> Move the Variables of Interest into the 'dependent list' box -> Plots -> Check option 'Normality plot with tests' Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Q-Q plots -> move the variables of interest into the 'variable' box. Z-Score: Distance from the mean in standard deviation units. Indicates how much a given value differs from the mean. A positive z-score indicates the raw score is higher than the mean average. For example, if a z-score is equal to +1, it is 1 standard deviation above the mean. A negative z-score reveals the raw score is below the mean average. For example, if the z-score is equal to -2, it is 2 standard deviations below the mean. It standardizes the distribution so that M = 0 and SD = 1. If data normally distributed: Sample Population
In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Descriptives -> Click save standardized values as variables -> move the variables you want z-scores for into the variable box -> check 'Save standardized values as variables' Statistical symbols are italicized M, SD, p, etc. There is a space on either side of the equality sign. M = 558.41, p < 0.001 Only use leading zeros if the value can be greater than 1. The average length was small (0.42 ft.) p < .001

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 5. Hypothesis Testing
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
State the H0 and H1. Define alpha level. Determine the critical values and the rejection regions. Calculate observes test statistics. Make decision. Reject or fail to reject the H0. Write conclusion. Specifying the direction (positive/negative, greater/lesser, etc.) during hypothesis testing. Non-Directional: Research Question: Are depression scores of male adolescents who do not engage in sports significantly different from the average male adolescent? H0: µ = Mean depression score for population (50) H1: µ ≠ 50 Directional: RQ: Are depression scores of male adolescents who do not engage in sports significantly lower than the average male adolescent? H0: µ = 50 H1: µ < 50 Occurs when a researcher rejects H0 when it is actually true Concludes that treatment has had an effect when it really hasn't; leads to the publication of false results Alpha level: The probability that the test will lead to a Type I Error. Occurs when a researcher fails to reject H0 when it's actually false Concludes that a treatment had no effect when it really did Probability of a Type II Error depends on a number of factors and cannot be reduced to a specific number Used when we are comparing a sample to the population Need: μ (mean) and σ (standard deviation) State the H0 and H1 Define the alpha (𝛼) level Compute z statistic, recall: zobs = (x-bar - µ0) / (𝜎 / √n) Look up critical value in z table Make decision to either reject or fail to reject the H0 Write conclusion Introduction to Syntax in SPSS (Ep.8) - YouTube
One sample z test - SPSS (Part1) - YouTube
[One sample z test - SPSS (Part 2) - YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qrNagh2qGz8 A school psychologist administered an intelligence test (WISC) to n = 128 children. Normed data provides the following information on the WISC for children in the US: µ = 100 𝜎 = 15 The psychologist obtained an average WISC score for her sample of . Is it reasonable for her to assume that the sample of children she administered the test to is drawn from the population on which the test is normed? Test using 𝛼 = .05. SPSS Output: z-statistic: 1.54621 p-value .12205 Cohens d .13667 A z-test was conducted to find out whether there exists a significant mean level different between the average WISC score for a sample of students and the national average. It was hypothesized that the mean WISC score of the sample of students is different from the national average. The results was not statistically significant [z (128) = 1.55, p = .12, d = 0.14], indicating that there is no difference between the sample average and the population average. This results therefore indicates that the sample data comes from the same national norms.

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 6. One Sample t-Test and Power of a Test
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description: (https://www.psychologie.hhu.de/arbeitsgruppen/allgemeine-psychologie-und-arbeitspsychologie/gpower) A one sample t-test evaluates whether the mean on a test variable is significantly different from a constant. Assumptions: The test variable is normally distributed in the population. The cases represent a random sample from the population. Scores on the test variables are independent of each other. State the H0 and H0 Define ⍺ level Compute t statistic Look up critical value in t-table/interpret output Make decision Reject or fail to reject the H0. Write conclusion Janet is interested in determining if depression scores of male adolescents who do not engage in sports are significantly different from the average male adolescent. To test this hypothesis, she obtains Kansas University Depression Inventory (KUDI) scores from 30 adolescent boys who have indicated on a questionnaire that they do not engage in sports outside of school gym classes. Past research has shown that the mean depression score for male adolescents in the population in the population is 50. Janet wants to determine if the mean KUDI score for the 30 adolescents is different from the value of 50. State the H0 and H1 H0: 𝜇 = 50 H1: 𝜇 ≠ 50 Define 𝛼 level 𝛼 = .05 Compute t-statistic Look up critical value in t-table and interpret output Make decision Reject or fail to reject the H0 Write conclusion Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-Sample t-test -> drag VOI into 'Test Variable(s)' box -> Enter the known population mean into the 'Test Value' box Click 'Estimate Effect Sizes' Click Options -> Enter Confidence Interval One Sample Statistics:One-Sample Test: tobs = 2.457 df = n - 1 = 30 - 1 = 29 tcrit = 2.045 Standard Error of the mean is: sy-bar = (sy) / √n 10.327 / √30 = 10.327 / 5.477 = 1.8855 95% of the time, the true population mean difference will fall between .78 and 8.49 95% of the time, the true population mean will fall between 50.78 and 58.49. t is the t-test statistic value t = 4.633 / 1.886 = 2.4565 The result of the t-test is significant (t = 2.457, df = 29, p = .020) at the 𝛼 = .05 significance level. Therefore, we reject H0. Take a look at the actual difference between the sample mean and the population mean: tobs = 2.457 vs. tcrit = 2.045 Are you comfortable calling that difference significant? Alternative (or Supplement) to significance value: Cohen's d Cohen's d is an effect size measure used to indicate the difference between two means. For one-sample t-test, d indicates how many standard deviations the sample mean is away from the hypothesized mean. If d = 1.0, the sample mean is one standard deviation away from the hypothesized mean. d = (x-bar - 𝜇0) / s d = t / √n Effect size measures strength of relationship: One-Sample Effect Sizes d = 2.457 / √30 = .4486 d = 4.633 / 10.327 = .4486 A lot of times before conducting your study you need to submit a power analysis. This lets you know what sample size you need to find an effect. Power is the probability that a test of significance will detect deviation from the null hypothesis if one truly exists. A Priori Power Determine how many cases you will need to have a good chance of detecting an effect of a specified size with the desired amount of power. Imagine you are designing a new study to see if depression scores are higher in a new group of students. Using alpha = .01, what sample size would you suggest to detect a 1/2 standard deviation difference from the population mean, with 90% power? In this example, we have one-tailed test. Effect size is 0.5, alpha level is 0.01 and the desired power is 0.90. Based on these criteria, the required sample size for our one-sample t-test is 55. A Post Hoc Power Determine how much power you would have if you had a specified number of cases. In SPSS example (Kudi), we have a two-tailed test. The observed effect size was 0.449. The alpha level we tested was 0.05, and the actual sample size was 30. Based on these criteria, the power hoc power is 0.662 A one sample t-test was conducted on the KUDI scores to evaluate whether their mean was significantly different from 50, the mean for male adolescent in general. The sample mean of 54.63 (SD = 10.33) was significantly different from 50, (t (29) = 2.46, p = .02). The 95% confidence interval for the KUDI mean ranged from 50.78 to 58.49. The effect size d of .45 indicates a medium effect (Cohen, 1988). The post hoc power of the test, given the sample size, two-tailed, alpha level, and observed effect size, was .662 (M = 54.63, SD = 10.33). Note for future reference: When SPSS reports a p-value of .000, we indicate it in the results section as 'p-value < .001.'

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 7. Paired Sample t-test
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
Used when we are comparing the same group of people in our sample at two different time points. Example: Before and after a treatment State the H0 and H1
Define alpha level
Compute t statistic
Interpret the output
Make decision
Write conclusion Fred wishes to determine whether children in regular education are hurt or helped academically by the inclusion of special education students in their classes. He has gained the cooperation of the seventh-grade teachers in two similar junior high schools to participate in his study. One school recently integrated special education students into their regular classroom, while the other one has not. The teachers in both school supply Fred the students’ raw scores on a standardized achievement test at the beginning of the year and at the end of the year. SPSS file contains 40 cases and 3 variables: Integ (1: regular education students who are not in integrated classroom; 2. Regular education students who are in the integrated classroom)
Pretest (achievement test score of regular education students at the beginning of the year)
Posttest (achievement test score of regular education students at the end of the year) Research Questions: Are there any significant differences between the pre-test and post-test achievement scores? State the H0 and H1 H0: 𝜇pretest = 𝜇posttest
H1: 𝜇pretest ≠ 𝜇posttest Define alpha level 𝛼 = .05 Compute t statistic Analyze -> Compare Means -> Paired-Samples t-test -> drag 'pre-test' VOI into the 'Variable 1' box and the 'post-test' VOI into the 'Variable 2' box. Interpret the output Cohen's effect size conventions for mean difference: Small Effect Size: .20
Medium Effect Size: .50
Large Effect Size: .80 Paired Samples StatisticsPaired Samples CorrelationsPaired Samples Test
t = d / (s / √n) = -6.575 / 2.257 = -2.91316
df = n - 1 = 39
Effect Size: d = x-bar / s or d = t / √n = -2.913 / √40 = -. 4609 Make decision Reject the null hypothesis because our obtained significance value was less than our predetermined alpha level (p = .006). Write conclusion A paired samples t-test was conducted to determine if there was a difference in the mean pretest and posttest achievement scores of regular education students. The test results indicated that, on average, the pretest achievement scores (M = 96.45, SD = 14.83) and posttest achievement scores (M = 103.03, SD = 18.53) were statistically different from each other (t(39) = -2.913, p = .006, d = -. 461). The null hypothesis that the pretest and posttest means were the same was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size d was -. 461. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as moderately small effect.

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 8. Independent Samples t-test
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
Used when we are comparing two separate groups of people in our sample Example: Boys vs. Girls (Quasi-experimental design); Treatment vs. Control (Experimental Design) State the H0 and H1 Define alpha level Compute t statistic Interpret the output Make decision Write conclusion Fred wishes to determine whether children in regular education are hurt or helped academically by the inclusion of special education students in their classes. He has gained the cooperation of the seventh-grade teachers in two similar junior high schools to participate in his study. One school recently integrated special education students into their regular classroom, while the other one has not. The teachers in both school supply Fred the students’ raw scores on a standardized achievement test at the beginning of the year and at the end of the year. SPSS file contains 40 cases and 3 variables: Integ (1: regular education students who are not in integrated classroom; 2. Regular education students who are in the integrated classroom) Pretest (achievement test score of regular education students at the beginning of the year) Posttest (achievement test score of regular education students at the end of the year) Research Questions: Is there a mean difference in pretest achievement scores between regular education students who are not in integrated classroom and in the integrated classroom? State the H0 and H1 H0: 𝜇pretest not integrated = 𝜇pretest integrated H1: 𝜇pretest not integrated ≠ 𝜇pretest integrated Define alpha level 𝛼 = .05 Compute t statistic In SPSS: Analyze -> Compare Means -> Independent-Samples t-test -> drag dependent variable (s) into the 'Test Variable (s)' box > drag the categorical variable into the 'Grouping Variable' box -> Define Groups -> enter the values of your grouping variables into 'Group 1' and 'Group 2' respectively t = (M1 - M2) / √(SD12/ n1) + (SD22/ n2) Before you assess the t-test results: You need to check the assumption of homogeneity of variance (equal variance) by checking the Levene's Test results. H0: The variances are the same. H1: The variances are different.
If significance level is ≥ .05, we have met the assumption of homogeneity of variance. Assess the t-test with the top row, 'Equal variances assumed.'
If significance level is < .05, we have failed to met the assumptions of homogeneity of variance. Assess the t-test with the bottom row, 'Equal variances not assumed.' Interpret the output Group StatisticsIndependent Samples Test The result of the t-test is not significant (t = -1.167, df = 38 (n1 + n2 - 2 = 15 + 25 - 2 = 38), p = .250) at the α =. 05 significance level. Therefore, we fail to reject H0 and conclude the means are equal between the two groups. The results of Levene's test is not significant (F (1,38) = .566, p = .465) at the α = .05 significance level. Therefore, we fail to reject H0 and conclude the variances are equal between the two groups. Go to the top row, 'Equal variances assumed' (F(k-1, N-k)) (k: number of groups; N = sample size) Independent Samples Effect Sizes Effect Size: d = t x √(n1 + n2) / (n1 x n2) d = (-1.167) √ (15 + 25) / (15 x 25) Make decision Fail to reject the null hypothesis because our obtained significance value was greater than our predetermined alpha level (p = .250) Write conclusion An independent samples t-test was conducted to determine if the mean pretest achievement scores of regular education students who were not in an integrated classroom differed from regular education studetns who were in the integrated classroom. The test results indicate that, on average, the pretest means were not statistically significantly different for students who were not in the integrated classroom (M = 92.93, SD = 14.56) and students who were in the integrated classroom (M = 98.56, SD = 14.88); (t (38) = -1.167, p = .250, d = -. 381). The null hypothesis that the pretest means were the same for students in the integrated and not in the integrated classroom was retained at the .05 level of significance. The effect size d was -. 381. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a small effect. Is there a mean difference in posttest achievement scores between regular education students who are not in integrated classroom and in the integrated classroom? H0: 𝜇posttest not integrated = 𝜇posttest integrated H1: 𝜇posttest not integrated ≠ 𝜇posttest integrated Group StatisticsIndependent Samples Test The results of the Welch's t-test is significant (t' = -2.731, df = 37.952, p = .010) at the α = .05 significance level. Therefore, we reject H0 and conclude the means are not equal between the two groups. The results of Levene's test is significant (F (1,38) = 14.620, p < .001) at the α = .05 significance level. Therefore, we reject H0 and conclude the variances are not equal between the two groups. Write-Up: An independent samples t-test was conducted to determine if the mean post-test achievement scores of regular education students who were not in an integrated classroom differed from regular education students who were in the integrated classroom. The test results indicate that, on average, the post-test means were statistically significantly different for students who were not in the integrated classroom (M = 94.47, SD = 11.51) and students who were in the integrated classroom (M = 108.16, SD = 20.19); (t (38) = -2.731, p = .010, d = - .678). The null hypothesis that the pre-test means were the same for students in the integrated and not in the integrated classroom was retained at the .05 level of significance. The effect size d was -.678, which is interpreted as a small effect.

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 9. Correlations and SLR (Part I)
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
In a sense, regression is taking correlation a step further. Correlation captures the strength and direction of a linear relationship. Regression goes beyond looking at just the linear relationship. We are interested in predicting one variance with another. y: Dependent/Outcome Variance (we would like to predict) x: Independent/Predictor Variable(s) We are predicting y from x y-hat = b0 + b1X y-hat: Outcome Variable (DV) x: Predictor Variable (IV) b1: Slope (Regression coefficient) r ((sx)/(sy)) b0: y-intercept Y-bar - b1 (x-bar) John had 80 men complete a self-concept inventory that contains five scales. Four scales involve questions about how competent respondents feel in the areas of intimate relationships, relationships with friends, commonsense reasoning and everyday knowledge, and academic reasoning and scholarly knowledge. The fifth scale includes items about how competent a person feels in general. For this example, John is interested in conducting a regression analysis with the scale how competent respondents feel in relationship with friends as the predictor and the scale how competent they feel in general as the dependent variable. Descriptive Statistics Friends: Skewness ratio: -. 552 Kurtosis Ratio: .021 Both skewness ratio and kurtosis ratio statistics are within +/- 2 range. Therefore, the distribution of friends would be considered normal. General: Skewness ratio: .004 Kurtosis Ratio: -. 721 Both skewness ratio and kurtosis ratio statistics are within +/- 2 range. Therefore, the distribution of general would be considered normal. Analyze -> Correlate -> Bivariate -> drag VOIs into 'Variables' box Under 'Correlation Coefficients' select which type of correlation you want (Pearson) Under 'Test of Significance' select which type of test you want, based on your hypothesis Spearman's rank order correlation coefficient Measures the strength and direction of association between two ranked variables Example: Math and science scores of students Phi Coefficient Between two dichotomous variables Gender (male, female) Coin Flip (heads, tails) Cramer's V When variables have more than two categories Political affiliation Race Create the correlation table in SPSS and double click the table. Using the Pivot -> Pivoting Trays menu, remove 'Statistics' from the 'Row' box and place it in the 'Layer' bod in the top left of this pop-out menu (the process we went over in class) Click Format ->TableLooks -> select 'APA_TimesRoma_12 pt' Copy and paste this 'cleaned' correlation table into Excel/Word. When pasting, use the 'Match Destination Format' option Center align the correlation coefficients and the column headers (the row headers remain left-aligned) Delete the correlation coefficients above the diagonal Number the variables along the left side of the correlation table Replace the column header variable names with the corresponding numbers you just made. Replace the '1 s' that make up the diagonal with '-' Place borders: Below the last row Above and below the column headers Make sure the font is Times New Roman and the font size is 12. Correlation coefficients were computed among five self-concept scales. The results of the correlation analysis are presented in Table 1. The correlations of academic self-concept with other self-concept measures tend to be lower. The strongest correlation was between friends self-concept and intimate self-concept (r = .552). In research papers, correlations are typically discussed along with descriptive statistics, sometimes being reported within the same table. They are used to describe how the variables in your data relate to one another. Typically, correlations are just presented in a table, after (or with) the descriptive statistics. Having the legend of ** is common. Typically remove 'top diagonal' because the information is redundant Sometimes the top and bottom diagonal will represent two groups (i.e., males and females)
Analyze -> Regression -> Linear -> drag outcome variable into the 'dependent' box -> drag the predictor variable into the 'Block 1 of 1' box In the Statistics menu, select Estimates, Confidence Intervals, Model Fit, and Descriptive
The constant (b0) = 32.930 The slope (regression coefficient) = .386 The estimated model: Y-hat = b0 + b1X General-hat = 32.93 + 0.386 Friends Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Simple Scatterplot' into the preview box -> drag predictor to the x-axis and outcome to the y-axis To add the regression line, double-click the scatterplot, click the Add Fit Line at Total button

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 1. Introduction to Educational Statistics
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
Population: All members of a well-defined group (people, animals, parts produced in a factory, districts, schools, etc.)
Sample: A subset of a population. Generally, it is too difficult (time-consuming, costly, ineffecient) to collect data on the entire population (census) so we take a sample.
We draw a Sample (data) from the Population of research interest and make inference (Generalization) back to population.
Population of Interest
Draw Sample Compute Sample Statistics
Make Inference Back to the Population
Parameter: A characteristic of a population.
Statistic: A characteristic of a sample.
The parameters in Population are often unknown, but we can estimate them from our sample statistics. Parameters are usually notated by Greek alphabet. Sample statistics are usually notated by English alphabet.
A good Sample should be: Identical to the characteristics/properties of the population. Representative of a population. This allows the sample to be generalizable to the population. Results will be applicable to other samples drawn from the same population. Every member of the population of interest has an equal probability of being selected. Selection of one unit has no effect on the selection of another unit. Best technique to obtain a representative sample. Use a number table, a compute, a drawing, or a lottery system to generate random numbers. Use if one or more characteristics are focal research interest. The goal is to compare groupds (strata). The purpose is to make sure each group is represented in the sample. First divide population into groups (strata). Then a random sample is taken from each group. There are 'naturally occurring' groups in population, usually geographical or organizational. Randomly selected clusters. Then sample all units within each cluster, or random sample with each chosen cluster. Error is smaller if the clusters are similar to each other. Every k^th unit is selected from a list, where k=population/desired sample size. Have a list with all units in the population. Then take sample systematically. Make sure the list you are selecting from is random. Choose samples merely based on proximity without considering whether they represent the population or not. Readily available, quick, inexpensive.
Can reduce bias by using conveniance sample along with Simple Random Sample (SRS), taking multiple samples, or cross-validation. Is the sample representative of the population? (Are the findings generalizable?) Sample size? The larger sample does not mean more representative of the population. Required sample size depends on design, confidence level, desired effect size and statistical power. Generally, 30 or more per combinations of factors. How to report: Define your population Describe sampling procedure Indivate desired sample size Indicate actual sample size Provide descriptions of the sample and inferences from the analyses
Variable: Any characteristic of persons or things that is observed to take on different values. Constant: Any characteristic of persons or things that is observed to take on only a single value. Role of variables:
Dependent (outcome/target) vs. Independent (predictors/input) Types of variables: Qualitative (Categorical) Quantitative (Numeric) Phenomena or variables that can be used to describe a quality of a person or item. Categorical Dichotomous variables can only take on 2 different values (e.g., yes or no). Example: County of residence, religion, political affiliation, ethnicity Dichotomous: Sex assigned at birth (male or female) Whether a person voted in an election (yes or no). Variables that describe a numerical aspect of characteristic of a person or phenomena. Discrete: A numerical variable that arises from the counting process that can take on only certain values.
Continuous: A variable that can take on any value within a certain range, given a precise enough measurement instrument. Example: Discrete: Count of students enrolled in a course, # of clinic visits, agreement level to a survey item
Continuous: Distance between two cities, checking account balance, time to rune a marathon, GPA Numbers can be assigned to the possible outcomes or responses that can occur for any variable, regardless of how it is classified (i.e., qualitative or quantitative). Measurement: The process of assigning numbers to phenomena in order to represent or distinguish among responses. Represent the features and properties of a variable. Help us understand how to describe and analyze the data. S. S. Stevens (1951) developed 4 types of measurement scales that could be used for assigning these values: Usually used for qualitative/categorical variables Numbers mark distinctions between responses, and nothing more. The numbers have no inherent meaning, and the order does not matter at all. Example: County of residence (1=Franklin, 2=Delaware, 3=Union OR 1=Delaware, 2=Union, 3=Franklin) Sex assigned at birth (0=female, 1=male OR 10=female, 15=male) In SPSS, can set value labels and display either data or label. Numbers are assigned to represent ranks or order (usually discrete). Numbers have meaning, but only in terms of distinguishing order, from largest to smallest (or vice versa). Equal distance between two adjacent levels are not assumed. Example: Letter grades: A, B, C, D, E (1-5) Size of a cup of coffee (small, medium, large, 1-3) Socioeconomic status (SES) (low, middle, high, 1-3) Agreement (Likert Scale) (strongly agree, neutral, disagree, strongly disagree, 1-5) Sometimes data needs to be recorded to make interpretation more intuitive Equal intervals or increments along the scale Interval variables have an arbitrary zero point. Example: Temperature Celsius or Fehrenheit, SAT score, credit score Likert Scale (equal distance assumed): More choices for statistical methods are available for interval data than ordinal data. Decisions might depend on your data. Report range to help readers understand the measure. Equal intervals or increments along the scale and contains an absolute and true zero point (absence of the phenomena being measured, data measures from 0 and above). It is possible to compare 2 values and say one is 'twice as large' or 'two-third the size' Statistical Package for the Social Sciences Open the SPSS application File -> New -> Data File -> Open -> Data -> select the desired file File -> Open -> Data -> change 'Files of Type' to: Excel -> select the desired file File -> Import Data -> Excel -> select the desired file If the excel file has column titles, click 'Read variable names' from the first row of data. Each row represents a case (person, school, state, etc.) Each column represents a specific variable Must begin with a letter The rest can contain a combination of numbers and letters Can use periods and underscore, but no other symbol Numeric (most common) Date Dollar String (second most common, only Type where you can use letters) How many characters are allowed inside the cell (string variables) How many decimal places are allowed in the cell Where you can further define the variables Used when numbers in the data file represent something Where you can define certain values to be considered 'missing' Helps to adjust the size/width of the columns is data view Nominal: Used for nominal variables such as ID numbers and when numbers represent something Ordinal: Used for ordinal data Scale: Used for ratio and interval data

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 2. Data Representation
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
Useful for nominal and ordinal variables. Report counts and/or percentages A frequency table, bar chart, or pie chart might not be meaningful to depict interval/ratio variables. More graphs and statistics are available to represent interval/ratio variables. Similar to a frequency table, but data is categorized into groups. Show both raw data and shape of distribution (like a histogram). First find range of data (Max - Min) then break into multiple groups with equal intervals. Stem: Categories Groups Leaf: Data points Key: An example of the stem and leaf to show what number it represents. This allows readers to determine the placement of each digit in the stem and leaf. (SPSS reports the stem width) Example: 5|2 = 52 Frequency (Absolute Frequency): The number of times the observation occurred/recorded in an experiment or study.
Relative Frequency (between 0 and 1): The ratio of the frequency of a particular event in a statistical experiment to the total frequency.
Can be reported with intervals or real limits (the lower or upper value for a continuous variable measured on a ratio scale). For example: Interval: 50-59 Real Limit: (49.5-59.5) Visualize frequency of data. X-axis label can be midpoints of interval, or real limits, Y-axis can be frequency or relative frequency
The bars are equal intervals and continuous data (no gaps). Show the shape of the distribution. SPSS: Can modify the bin width in Chart Editor -> select columns -> Binning Proportion of scores from this category and lower. Related to percentile rank: Percentage of scores in a distribution that are equal to or less than that score. X-axis: Data (score)
Y-axis: Cumulative Relative Frequency (or Cumulative Frequency) Example
Global Customer Support Manager Salaries: The percentile rank of a given score is the percent of observations falling at or below that score. Start at the bottom (x-axis) to locate the score of interest, then move up to the ogive and over to the Y-axis. Example: Percentile rank for $50,000? PR $50,000 = 61% 61% of global customer support managers earn salary at or below $50,000. Every data point in a distribution has an associated percentile. Start on the Y-axis to locate the percent of interest, then move horizontally to the ogive and then down to the X-axis. Example: Find 80th percentile (P 80) P 80= $66,000 (approximately) About 80% of global customer support managers earn salary at or below $66,000. First make sure the measurement level has been set properly for the variable. Go to Graphs -> Chart Builder In Gallery, select Line and drag Simple Line to the preview section Mat gave to hit Reset from previous charts. Under Element Properties, Statistic, select Cumulative Percentage The preview does not make much sense, but it is okay. Just submit to see the actual graph. Minimum (or 10th percentile, P10) Q1: First Quartile (or 25th percentile, P25) Median (or 10 th percentile, P50) Q3: Third Quartile (or 75th percentile, P75) Maximum (or 90th percentile, P90) Each sections 25% of data. The box contains 50% of data: Interquartile range IQR = Q3 - Q1
Minimum: Q 1 = 1.5 X IQR (the data point above it) Maximum: Q 3 + 1.5 X IQR (the data point below it) Outliers (Circles): More than 1.5 IQR from the upper or lower of the box Extreme values (asterisks): More than 3 times the IQR!
Box plots are useful as they provide a visual summary of the data enabling resarchers to quickly identify: Median (center) of data Dispersion (spread) of data Skewness of data Potential outliers/extreme values
Box Plot Explained: Interpretation, Examples, & Comparison

Depict the relationship between two variables by plotting the pair of scores on x and y for each record on a two-dimensional figure (coordinate). X-axis represents the values for variable x (usually IV).
Y-axis represents the values for variable y (usually DV). The scatterplot is useful for providing a quick indication of the nature of the relationship among variables x and y (bivariate data). Direction of the relationship (positive or negative): A positive relationship occurs when both variables are increasing. A negative (inverse) relation occurs when one variable is increasing as the other is decreasing. Can draw a straight line (aka regression line) through the data points that cuts the bivariate distribution in hald. The slope of the regression line shows the direction of relationship. Alternatively, split the chart into 4 equal sections (quadrants) and examine how data points are spread across the 4 quadrants. Strength of the relationship: Strong relationships: Data points tend to fall close to the regression line. Weak relationship: Data points are widely scattered around the regression line. Summary of the scales of measurement Also referred to as Demographics Table In research, typically used to describe your sample Sex/Gender, Race/Ethnicity, Level of Education, etc. Only used to display discrete data. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> drag variable (s) of interest (VOI) into 'Variables' box -> select 'Display Frequency Tables' box in bottom left-hand corner of the menu. Unfortunately, SPSS does not provide us with output that is 'APA-Ready' In order to create an APA-style frequency (demographics) table, you need to use Excel (or similar program) When do we use them? Nominal or ordinal data (discrete data) There are two ways to produce Bar Graphs, each produces the same graph. SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> Charts -> 'Bar Charts' Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Bar' to the previewer, place variable of interest on x-axis. Note that the bars are separated by some space and do not touch one another, reflecting the nature of nominal data being discrete. When do we use them? Nominal or ordinal data (discrete data) In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> Charts -> 'Pie Charts' Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Pie/Polar' to the previewer, place variable of interest on x-axis. When do we use them? Displaying interval and ratio data (continuous data) Checking for the shape of the distribution Skewness, normality There are three different ways to produce histograms using SPSS, but each produces the same graph. Typically making them while producing other descriptive statistics, so that will guide which menu you use. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> Charts -> 'Histogram' Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore -> Plots -> 'Histogram' Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Histograms' to the previewer -> drag the variable of interest to the x-axis.
Normal Distribution: Mode = Median = Mean Negatively Skewed (Skewed to the Left, tail toward the left): Mode > Median > Mean Positively Skewed (Skewed to the right, tail toward the right): Mode < Median < Mean Used to display interval and ratio data. Not used often in publications, but can be useful for visualizing your data. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore -> Plots -> 'Stem-and-Leaf' Not used as much in academic publications, but still valuable in visualizing your data. In SPSS: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Explore -> Plots -> it is clicked by default Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Boxplot' to the previewer -> drag the variable of interest to the x-axis and drag the scale variable to the y-axis. The box in the center displays the middle 50% of the distribution. The bottom edge of the box represents the 25 th percentile (or Q 1) The top edge of the box represents the 75 th percentile (or Q 3) The middle thick vertical line in the box represents the 50 th percentile (also known as Q 2 or the median) The lines extending from the box are known as the whiskers. The purpose of whiskers is to display data outside of the middle 50%. Range: Min - Max
Shape of the Distribution:
Used to display interval and ratio data Not used that often (histograms are the preferred display) In SPSS: Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Line' to the previewer -> drag the VOI to the x-axis On the right, change statistics to 'Cumulative Percentage' On the output window, double click on the graph and click 'Show Grid Lines' Select 'Both major and minor ticks' then click 'Apply' Percentile Score below which a certain percentage of the distribution lies P% = score Percentile Rank Percentage of a distribution of scores that falls below (or is less than a certain score) PRscore = % Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies -> drag VOI into the box -> Statistics -> select Quartiles and Percentiles -> type the number into the box to the right of percentiles and click 'add.' This gives you the percentile of the number and the first quartile (25 th percentile), second quartile (median / 50 th percentile) and third quartile (75 th percentile). A plot of two scale (interval or ratio) variables Helps to visually identify possible relationship between two variables. Graphs -> Chart Builder -> drag 'Scatter/Dot' to the previewer -> drag one of the VOI to the x-axis and the other to y-axis.
In SPSS, you can create new variables from old variables. In the menu bar, go to transform. Select Compute Variable. In the pop-up window that shows up, give a name for the new target variable. Define your new variable in the Numeric Expression Box Click OK Recoding variables in SPSS involves altering variable values to create a new modified variable, typically done during data preparation and analysis to better suit analysis needs or simplify the data. In the menu bar, go to Transform. Select Recode to Different Variables. It is not recommended to Recode into Same Variables as this overwrites existing variables.

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 3. Descriptive Statistics
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
What do we do when we have research questions about a large sample of data? Carrying around the entire collection of data would be very difficult. Descriptive statistics summarize the data in an abbreviated fashion, but they provide sufficient information to depict the data. 𝑥i: The score for ith person in the study or data set on variable x. Taking the sum of a set of scores is utilized quite often in statistics so we need a common system of notation for communicating about summation. En=1 xi: The sum of all data points of variable x. i=1 is the lower limit or beginning of the summation. i=n refers to the last person or the end of a data set. Ages from a sample of 10 coworkers: 24, 26, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 n= 10 observations (subjects) Use N to notate size of the entire population. E10=1 xi = 24+26+28+28+31+31+31+35+38+47 = 318 Excel: =SUM (data range) All excel formulas in this class are optional (but useful) A single index or value summarizing the entire collection of scores. Three most popular measures of central tendency are mean, median, and mode. Mode: Most common or frequent value Median (Mdn): 50th percentile (or Q 2) or the middlemost value of an ordered set of scores. Mean: Arithmetic average The value in a distribution of scores that occurs most frequently. Sometimes there is no mode, and sometimes there are multiple modes. When there are two modes (bimodal distributions), some people report both modes. If they are adjacent, some people average the two modes. Goal is to faithfully describe the distribution of your data. Coworker example: 24, 26, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 A new guy just joined the team: 24, 26, 28, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 Can be used with any type of measurement scales. Pros: simple to obtain, the only appropriate measure for nominal data. Cons: does not always have a unique value, not a function of all scores, difficult to deal with mathematically. We already know a lot about median (P50 or Q 2): Middle most value in an ordered set of data. After ordering the data, locate the ((n+1)/2) th observation. Coworker example (odd number): 24, 26, 28, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 New guy just quit (even number): 24, 26, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 Can be used with ordinal, interval, and ratio scales. Pros: Not influenced by extreme scores (outliers) Always has a unique value Cons: Not a function of all scores Difficult to deal with mathematically Sample Mean = (sum of xi)/n Coworker example: 318/10 = 31.8 Excel: =Average (data range) Used to estimate population mean The larger our sample, the better our estimate of the true population mean. Only appropriate for interval and ratio measurement scales. Pros: Function of every score. Always has a unique value. Easy to deal with mathematically. Most stable of the measures of central tendency. Cons: Influenced by extreme scores. Very unusual or 'extreme'values tend to draw the mean towards these values and contribute to skew in the data. Coworker example: 24, 26, 28, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46 Mean: 31.8 Median: 31 Mode: 31 A retired guy just rejoined the team: 24, 26, 28, 28, 28, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38, 46, 75 Mean: 393/11 = 35.7 Median: 31 Mode: 31 For samples from a symmetric distribution (e.g., normal), mean, median, and mode should be very close to each other. When mean, median, and mode are far from each other, the data is skewed. Skewed to the right (long right tail, positive skew): Extreme large values Skewed to the left (long left tail, negative skew): Extreme small values
Sometimes we may have the means of several groups of people, and we still want to find the average. Two ways to do this: Weighted Average (average all the original scores): Takes into account of each group's sample size. Average is appropriate 'weighted' by number of observations in each group. Unweighted Average (simply take the mean of the averages): Does not 'weight' or take account of the different sample sizes. AKA: mean of means, grand mean, usually used for group comparison. Example (Weight Average): 8150/100=81.5 Unweighted average: (85+80+75)/3=80 The mean alone is not enough to tell us about the shape of a distribution. Measures of dispersion describe the amount of variability among the scores (i.e., do the scores fall close to the central tendency measure or are the scores spread out?)
There are no measures of dispersion appropriate for nominal data. We already know two measures of dispersion: Range and Interquartile range (IQR) Both are measures of dispersion, but not a function of all scores. They are informative measures, but don't have very strong statistical properties. Difference between the largest and smallest scores. Pros: Simple to obtain. Cons: Influenced by extreme scores, only a function of two of the scores, unstable from sample to sample. Difference between the third quartile (Q 3) and the first quartiles (Q 1) AKA H spread (stands for hinge, middle 50% of the distribution), developed by Tukey. Pros: Unaffected by extreme scores. Cons: Not a function of all scores, not very stable from sample to sample. The 'average' squared deviation from the mean for a set of scores. Variance is a better measure of dispersion than range and IQR, because it takes into account all the values for a set of scores (but might be affected by extreme values). Conceptually, the variance is a measure of the area of the distribution (i.e., the more spread out the scores, the more area or space the distribution takes up). The sample mean might not be the same as the population mean (usually unknown), and the deviations would be affected. Therefore, sample variance obtained would be systematically too small. In order to get an unbiased sample estimate of the population variance, a slight change in the computational formula was made. AKA Degree of Freedom (df) When we calculate a simple statistic based in part on another statistic, we have to consider the 'degrees of freedom' in our calculation. Given the sample mean, we do not need raw data from all n observations. We only need (n-1) observations, because the last missing score can be found from the mean (i.e., there is no 'freedom' in what this score might be). The denominator (n-1) in sample variance is called the degrees of freedom (df), which is related to sample size. You may see many different forms of formulas out there to compute variances and forthcoming descriptive statistics. They all come from the same 'definitional' formula, but after being modified/simplified given the mathematical properties, some 'computational' formulas are easier to deal with by hand. But excel or SPSS will compute them for us anyway. Since variance is a squared value, it is difficult to interpret. The standard deviation (SD) is the square root of the variance, and it is the most common measure of dispersion. For population: 𝜎 = square root of 𝜎2 For sample: 𝜎 = square root of 𝜎2 Measured on the same scale as original data. Interpretation: On average, the deviations from the mean, but on average the distance from the mean is about 2.92. The 68-95-99.7 rule (more next time): About 68% of data points fall within +/- 1 standard deviation from the mean. About 95% of data points fall within +/- 2 standard deviations from the mean. About 99.7% of data points fall within +/- 3 standard deviations from the mean. Measure the shared variance (or co-variance) between variables x and y.
Difficult to interpret, because the value of covariance depends on the scale of the variables. Other measures are needed. Correlation coefficients are measures of relationship that are easier to interpret. The first correlation coefficient we consider is the Pearson correlation coefficient (usually notated as r), which measures the relationship between two interval or ratio variables.
Pearson r ranges from -1 to +/- 1 The sign denotes the direction of the relationship (positive or negative). The value denotes the strength: 0 is the weakest correlation. +1 and -1 are the strongest correlation. Correlation does not imply causation. Don't need the leading zero in APA style writing, because r does not go beyond +/-1. Central Tendency and Dispersion: Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Frequencies (uncheck option Display frequency tables) Descriptives Explore Correlation: Analyze -> Correlate -> Bivariate Correlation coefficients: Check Pearson To report covariance: Check option cross-product deviations and covariances Significances and p-values are also reported

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 4. Normal Distribution (Z-Scores)
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
The area of probability began in the Middle Ages (17th and 18th centuries). Royal and affluent gamblers consulted with mathematicians for advice on games of chance and gambling. Probability was also used for practical purposes to help determine life expectancy for life insurance policies. P(A) = S / T P(A) is probability of event A S is # of times event A can occur T is the total # of events possible Example with a fair six-sided die: P (4) = S/T = 1/6 P (x >/= 5) = 2/6 = 33.3% The sum of the probabilities for all possible outcomes is exactly 1 (i.e., 100% chance) The probability of any given event (a) cannot exceed 1 and (b) cannot be less than 0. An event having a probability of 1 means that no other event can possibly occur. "In this world nothing can be said to be certain, except death and taxes." (Benjamin Franklin, 1789) Related to 0, although you cannot speak of an event occurring less than never, you can have an event with 0 probability. "You can't win the lottery if you don't buy a ticket." Long ago many disciplines found that a particular bell-shaed or normal curve occurred often with many different variables (recall histograms). Later in the 1700 s, mathematicians were called on to find an equation to approximate the normal distribution. If an equation could be developed then the probability associated with any point on the curve could be determined. Until 1920, the development of the equation was attributed to Karl Friedrich Gauss, and it was known as the Gaussian curve. Then Pearson, however, found this equation written earlier than Gauss's time in an article by Abraham DeMoivre in 1733 and renamed the curve as the normal distribution. F (x): probability density function 𝜇: 'Location' parameter (center), can be estimated by sample mean 𝑥. 𝜎: 'Scale' parameter (spread), can be estimated by sample standard deviation s. 𝜋 ≈ 3.14159 𝑒 ≈ 2.71828
Normal distribution follows a very specific pattern: Symmetric around the mean (mean = median = mode) Bell-shaped Unimodal Aymptotic (the curve goes on forever on both sides of 𝜇) There are an infinite number of normal curves, one for every distinct pair of values of the mean and variance. Every member of the family of normal curves has the same characteristics except that the scale, mean, and variance can differ across different variables and populations. General Notation: 𝑥i~𝑁(𝜇, 𝜎2) Xi follow a normal distribution with mean 𝜇 and variance (𝜎2). Notice this notation reports variance (𝜎2), not standard deviation (𝜎). From a sample: 𝑥i~𝑁(𝜇, 𝜎2) For any random variable x, there are an infinite number of possibilities even within a small range. Theoretically, probability of x being a specific value is zero. P (x=xobs)=0
For continuous data, we find probability always within a range or interval, but we can make that interval as small as we like. Probability: Area under the curve between two values. Normal Curve (68-95-99.7 rule): 68.3% of scores are expected to fall within 1 standard deviation of the mean. (𝑥 ± 1s) 95.4% of scores are expected to fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean (𝑥 ± 2s) 99.7% of scores are expected to fall within 3 standard deviations of the mean (𝑥 ± 3s) We can convert any normal distribution to a standard normal distribution (aka unit normal distribution or standard unit normal distribution). Z-score: The standardized scores. This allows us to evaluate an individual's performance relative to the scores in the distribution. Make comparisons between two different individuals, or across two different variables. Identify extreme values (outliers)
Notation: 𝑥i~𝑁(0,1) Mean is 0. Variance (and standard deviation) is 1. To standardize, center mean to 0 and transform (stretch or compress) standard deviation to 1. Equation: zi = (xi-𝜇)/𝜎 For sample data: zi = (xi-𝜇)/s Useful equation: Xi=(𝜇+zi)(𝜎) Xi=(x+zi)(s) for sample data A typical z-table reports cumulative probability given a z score (i.e., area under the curve to the left of z, think PRz=%). We can determine any area under the curve (below or above a give z, or between any two z values). We can also find a specific z value given the cumulative probability (think P%=z). 68.3% of data within 1 standard deviation from the mean? P (z ≤ 1) - P (z ≤-1)= 0.8413 - 0.1587 = 0.6826 95.4% data within 2 standard deviations from the mean? P (z ≤ 2) - P (z ≤ -2) = 0.9772 - 0.0228 = 0.9544 99.7% data within 3 standard deviations from the mean? P (z ≤ 1) - P (z ≤ -1) = 0.9987 - 0.0013 = 0.9974 In a recent census, the average income for several large rural counties was 𝜇 = $35, 285 and the standard deviation was 𝜎 = $7,200. What proportion of families have incomes below $35,000? Want to find P (x<35000) Convert x ($) to z, given mean and standard deviation: Z = (x-𝜇)/𝜎 = (35000-35285)/7200 = -0.04 So we are looking for P (z ≤ -0.04) = 0.4840 About 48.4% of families had household incomes below $35,000. What was the 80th percentile household income? Use z-table to find the z score with cumulative probability 80% (area is 0.8000). Z = 0.845 (between 0.84 and 0.85 from table) Convert to $ (recall z = (x-𝜇)/𝜎): X = (𝜇 + z)(𝜎) = (35,285 + 0.845)(7200) ≈ 41369 The 80th percentile household income was $41,369. Learning a new instrument is exciting, but it takes consistent practicing to truly make music. A study shows aspiring musicians usually spend about 30 minutes practicing every day, with a standard deviation of 12.5 minutes. Assuming the practice time follows a normal distribution, what is the probability of a student practicing more than 70 minutes a day? We want to find P (x > 70) Convert x to z, given mean and standard deviation: Z = (x-𝜇)/𝜎) = (70-30)/12.5 = 3.2 So we are looking for P (z > 3.2) From z-table, P (z ≤ 3.2) = 0.9993 (table only gives area to the left. ) So P (z > 3.2) = 1-0.9993 = 0.0007 There is only a slight chance (0.07%) that a student would practice more than 70 minutes a day. The GAD-7 (Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item assessment) is a short questionnaire used to screen for anxiety. GAD-7 scores range from 0 to 21 and indicate the severity of generalized anxiety. In a clinical study based on 90 participants, the distribution of GAD-7 scores followed a normal distribution with a mean of 6.3 and a standard deviation of 2.8. Given the descriptive statistics, how many participants were considered to have moderate anxiety? Probability between 10 and 15 is P (x ≤ 15) - P (x ≤ 10). I used range 10-15 to include the score of 14. P (z ≤ (15-6.3)/2.8) - P (z ≤ 3.11) - P (z ≤ 1.32) From z-table: 0.991 - 0.9066 = 0.0925 ≈ 9.3% About 9.3% of the 90 participants had a GAD-7 score between 10 to 14. That is about 8 individuals (90 x 9.3% ≈ 8) who were considered to have moderate anxiety. The average June daily high temperature in Ohio is 80˚F, with a standard deviation of 3 degrees. Normality assumed, what are the expected range (high and low) of daily high temperatures 95% of the time? Find the middle 95% range from z-table: each tail is (1-0.95)/2 = (0.05/2) = 0.025 Z for upper limit (can be notated as z0.025): 1.96 (area to the left is 0.9750) Z for lower limit: -1.96 (area to the left is 0.0250) Notice the two z scores have the same value but different signs (symmetric). Middle 95% range for z: 0 ± 1.96 or (-1.96, 1.96) Convert to temperature (𝜇 ± 1.96 x 𝜎): 80 ± 1.96 x 3 = 80 ± 5.88 = (74.86) 95% of the time, June daily high temperature in Ohio fluctuates between 74˚F and 86˚F. Analyze -> Descriptive Statistics -> Descriptives Check option Save standardized values as variables. Negative and decimal values occur in a standard normal distribution, thus other types of standardized scores have been developed, such as: SAT (College Board): µ = 500, 𝜎 = 100 IQ: µ = 100, 𝜎 = 15 Normal Curve Equivalent (NCE): µ = 50, 𝜎 = 21.06 Many analyses require the normality assumption (i.e., variables should be normally distributed in the populaiton). Most tests are robust against such violations if sample size is large (30). However, non-normality is often associated with biased standard deviations, which affects decision making in hypothesis testing. If non-normality is severe, we might need to transform the data. For non-normal and small samples, other alternative nonparametric tests are available. Recall boxplot: Is the median in the middle of the box? Recall Central Tendency: Is median close to the mean? Compare Histogram (data) to normal curve (theory): SPSS: In Histogram, check option Display normal curve. Skewness and kurtosis ratios within ±2 or ±3. Forthcoming: Q-Q plot (quantile-quantile plot) Tests for normality: Kolmogorov-Smirnov test and Shapiro-Wilk test "Whenever the smallest or the largest observation is less than one standard deviation from the mean, this is evidence of severe skew." This suggests that the distribution of scores is very compressed on one side of the mean. SPSS measures skewness by the 3 rd moment about the mean: ∑(z3/n) If normal, this measure should be 0. Negative (Skew to the left) Positive (Skew to the right) Skewed if standardized skewness |skew÷se (skew)| ≥ 2 (large sample) or ≥ 3 (small sample) Se(skew) is the standard error of the skewness measure. Access "whether or not there are more or fewer extreme scores than expected in a normal distribution." Generally, kurtosis is less concerning than skewness. SPSS measures kurtosis by the 4th moment about the mean: ∑(z4÷n) - 3 If normal (mesokurtic), this measure should be 0. Negative kurtosis (platykurtic): flat or broad Positive kurtosis (leptokurtic): slender or narrow Non-normal if standardized kurtosis |kurtosis÷se (kurtosis)| ≥ 2 (large sample) or ≥ 3 (small sample) is the standard error of the kurtosis measure.
Statistics Skewness: / = (-0.978) / (0.083) = -11.78 Negative skew (to the left) Kurtosis / = (0.899) / (0.167) = 5.38 Leptokurtic (narrow) Descriptive Statistics Statistics Skewness: / = (0.089) / (0.083) = 1.07 Within ±2: Normal Kurtosis / = (-0.677) / (0.167) = -4.05 Leptokurtic (narrow)
