university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 5. Sampling Distribution of the Mean (One-Sample Z-Test)
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
Here we begin to move from descriptive statistics to inferential statistics. After collecting sample data and generating sample statistics, we may also want to know to what extend we can generalize from these sample statistics to their corresponding population parameters (e.g., What does x tell us about µ?) We already understand how probability and distribution(s) work. Now we want to know (a) how much uncertainty exists in our sample statistics, and (b) how much confidence can we place in our sample statistics. Inferential statistics allow us to make an inference or generalization from a sample to the population. Step 1: Population of interest Step 2: Draw sample Step 3: Compute sample statistics Step 4: Make inference back to the population Allows you to grow 30 plants simultaneously in just two square feet. Designed specifically for indoor growing - no dirt, no mess. LED-light column design boosts plant growth, makes it easier to maintain and brings natural beauty to your home. AI-powered with 24/7 plant monitoring. N = 20 Mean µ = 181.9 225.36 Each sample has n = 4 All sample means 𝑥 have been calculated. Mean of the sampling distribution of the mean µx = 165.36 Standard Error of the Mean 𝜎x = 121.48 How does 𝜎x compare to 𝜎? In our Gardyn pricing experiment, we took random samples of size n = 4 students and recorded each sample's mean x1, x2, x3,… and many other samples. Each sample mean is a point estimate of the population mean. We can construct a frequency distribution of sample means, known as the sampling distribution of the mean. It is the distribution of x for all possible samples of size n. The mean of the sampling distribution of the mean (µx) is the estimate of population mean (i.e., µx = µ). Sampling error (x - µx): the difference (deviation) between a particular sample mean and the population mean. Variance error of the mean (𝜎 2/x): the variance of the sampling distribution of the mean. Standard error of the mean (𝜎x): the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the mean. As sample size n increases (say 30), the sampling distribution of the mean from a random sample more closely approximates a normal distribution. If the population distribution is normal, then the sampling distribution of the mean is also normal in shape. If the population distribution is not normal, then the sampling distribution of the mean becomes more nearly normal as sample size increases ('approximately normal') In reality, we'd only draw sample once and observe one sample mean x (i.e., 𝜎x is not calculated from various samples). According to CLT, we can use x to estimate µ with the standard error of the mean 𝜎x = (𝜎 ÷ √n) CLT tells us the theoretical distribution of the sample mean x so we don't have to take hundreds of samples, find their mean and variance or create a histogram in order to use this information! We can create a confidence interval (CI) for the mean: Rather than a point estimate for a population parameter, we can construct an interval estimate (i.e., the likely range capturing the population parameter). Hypothesis tests about the mean. So we can make a decision about a parameter based on sample data. Allow us to move from descriptive statistics to inferential statistics. Recall last time: Convert a data point x to z-score: z = (x - µ) ÷ 𝜎 Now, since sampling distribution of the mean follows a normal distribution: Mean: µx = µ Standard Error of the Mean: 𝜎x = 𝜎 ÷ √n To convert a sample mean x to z score: Z = (x - µ) ÷ 𝜎x = (x - µ) ÷ (𝜎 ÷ √n) Recall last time: In a recent census, the average income for several large rural counties was µ = $35,285 and the standard deviation was 𝜎 = $7,200. Now, suppose a sample of n = 400 households was randomly selected from this region. Describe the sample distribution of the mean. What is the probability that the average income from the sample is: Below $35,000? Exceeding $39,000? Between $35,000 and $35,500? According to CLT, the sampling distribution of the mean is approximately normal. Mean: µx = µ = $35,285 Standard Error of the Mean: 𝜎x = 𝜎 ÷ √n = $7,200 ÷ √400 = $360 Convert sample mean x to z score: z = (x - µ) ÷ 𝜎x = (x - 35285) ÷ 360. Or in one step: Z = (x - µ) ÷ (𝜎 ÷ √n) = (x - 35,285) ÷ (7,200 ÷ √400) Use z table to find the corresponding probability smaller than z. P (x < $35,000) = P (z < (35,000 - 35,285)÷360) = P (z < -0.79) = 21.48%. P (x < $39,000) = P (z < (39,000 - 35,285)÷360) = P (z > 10.32) = 1 - P (z < 10.32) ≈ 0. It is extremely unlikely to observe a sample mean more than $39,000. P ($35,000 < x < $35,500) = P ((35,000 - 35,285) ÷ 360) < z < ((35,500 - 35,285) ÷ 360) = P (-0.79 < z < 0.60) = P (z < 0.60) - P (z < -0.79) 0.7257 -0.2148 = 51.09% Given a confidence level 100 (1 - 𝛼)%, we can build an interval estimates for the population mean from sample mean (x). The most common confidence level is 95% (𝛼 = 0.05). Reported as lower confidence limit (LCL) and upper confidence limit (UCL), aka lower confidence bound (LCB) and upper confidence bound (UCB). General form: 100 (1 - 𝛼)& CI = x ± za/2x 𝜎x (Recall 𝜎x = 𝜎 ÷ √n) 90% CI = x ± 2.645 x 𝜎x 95% CI = x ± 1.96 x 𝜎x 99% CI = x ± 2.575 x 𝜎x Interpretation: The confidence interval will contain the true population mean 100 (1 - 𝛼) out of 100 times. Here we define the area in the tails as 𝛼. Since we have 2 tails, each tail is 𝛼 ÷ 2 This is for nondirectional CI. For directional, no need to find 𝛼 ÷ 2. Notice the table entry is the area under the curve to the left of z (i.e., PR), not the tail. Recall last time: The average June daily high temperature in Ohio is 80˚F, with a standard deviation of 3 degrees. 95% of the time, June daily high temperature in Ohio fluctuates between 74˚F and 86˚F. µ ± 1.96 x 𝜎: 80 ± 1.96 = 80 ± 5.88 (74, 86) Now, if we take a random sample of 100 June daily high temperatures from different dates/locations in Ohio, what is the sampling distribution of the mean? What is the 95% confidence interval (CI)? According to CLT, the sampling distribution of the mean is approximately normal. Mean: µx = µ = 80 Standard Error of the Mean: 𝜎x = 𝜎 ÷ √n = 3 ÷ √100 = 0.3 95% CI: µ ± 1.96 x 𝜎x: 80 ± 1.96 x 0.3 = 80 ± 0.588 ≈ (79.4, 80.6) Interpretation: With 95% confidence (i.e., 95 out of 100 times), our interval (79.5˚F, 80.6˚F) covers Ohio's true average June daily high temperature. 90% CI: µ ± 1.645 x 𝜎x: 80 ± 1.645 x 0.3 = 80 ± 0.4935 ≈ (79.5, 80.5) 99% CI: µ ± 2.575 x 𝜎x: 80 ± 2.575 x 0.3 = 80 ± 0.7725 ≈ (79.2, 80.8) Scores on a physical performance test for middle school students have been normed nationally for all students with a mean µ = 175 and a standard deviation 𝜎 = 12. We took a sample of n = 120 students in Ohio found that the sample mean x = 162. Ohio population might be different from national norm so x = 162 deviates from µ = 175. Suppose we'd like to estimate the population mean for Ohio based on this sample, what is the 95% confidence interval (CI)? Report the lower confidence limit (LCL) and the upper confidence limit (UCL). Population µ = 175, 𝜎 = 12, Ohio Sample x = 162, n = 120 95% CI for Ohio population: x ± za ÷ 2 x 𝜎x; or in one step: x ± za ÷ 2 x 𝜎 ÷ √n 162 ±1.96 x 12 ÷ √120 = 162 ± 2.147 = (159.853, 164.147) Interpretation: We can be 95% confident that our interval covers the true population mean for Ohio (i.e., 95 out of 100 times, this CI would contain the true value of mean for the population to which we are generalizing). But is Ohio mean 162 significantly different from 175 (i.e., is the Ohio population from which we drew our sample the same population used to create the national norm)? Observation: Since 175 falls outside of the 95% CI (159.853, 164.147) of Ohio mean, it is likely that Ohio population deviates from the national norm. Hypothesis testing is a decision-making process where two possible decisions are weighed in a statistical fashion. Hypotheses are written for each decision and then sample data are used to help make the decision. Here we examine a statistical test to make inferences about a single mean with a known population standard deviation (𝜎):
One-sample t-test (6. One-Sample T-Test, Power)
Two samples, paired data: Paired (7. Paired-Sample T-Test)
Two samples, independent groups: Independent t-test (8. Independent T-Test, Homogeneity of Variance) Null hypothesis (H0): A statement about the value of an unknown population parameter. There is no difference or a 'null' difference between the population and hypothesized means (statistical hypothesis, chance model). Alternative Hypothesis (H1 or Ha): The opposite of H0. The scientific hypothesis that the researcher believes the outcome of the study will be, based on previous research and theory (research hypothesis, your theory). Hypothesis testing in a nutshell: Compare sample statistics to hypothesized distribution. If the data evidence is extreme, we can reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the event did not happen by chance. Instead, our theory is supported by data. Set up hypotheses based on the research question. Where does the sample/observed mean lie on the sampling distribution? Given the confidence level 100 (1 - 𝛼)%, what is considered extreme evidence? Compared to the critical value is the sample mean extreme enough to be considered different from 𝜇0? Probability of Type I Error (what we want to avoid in decision making). Determine how far the sample mean needs to be from the hypothesized mean in order to reject H0. Set by the researcher or discipline, but the most commonly used values in the behavioral sciences and education are: 𝛼 = .05 (wrong 5% of the time, 95% confidence level) 𝛼 = .01 (wrong 1% of the time, 99% confidence interval) A statistician is a person whose lifetime ambition is to be wrong 5% of the time. Nondirectional (two-tailed): to test whether the population mean (𝜇) from which we drew sample equals a specific hypothesized value (𝜇0). Critical region can be either right (upper) or left (lower) tail. H0: 𝜇 = 𝜇0 H1: 𝜇 ≠ 𝜇0 Directional (one-tailed): To test whether the population mean (𝜇) from which we drew sample is significantly greater or less than a specific hypothesized value (𝜇0). Right (upper) tail (test if greater): H0: 𝜇 ≤ 𝜇0 vs. H1: 𝜇 > 𝜇0 Left (lower) tail (test if less): H0: 𝜇 ≥ 𝜇0 vs. H1: 𝜇 < 𝜇0

Used when population 𝜎 is known, to test if sample is drawn from the same population (𝜇0: hypothesized mean). Consider the research question and decide nondirectional or directional. Set up null and alternative hypotheses. Calculate observed z-score from sample statistics. Recall: zobs = (x bar - 𝜇0) ÷ (𝜎 / √𝑛) Given confidence level and direction, find the critical z-score and region from table. Compare zobs to zcrit and reject H0 if zobs is in the critical region. Population 𝜇 = 175, 𝜎 = 12, Ohio sample x bar = 162, n = 120 Nondirectional (two-tailed) so the hypotheses are: H0: 𝜇 = 175 H1: 𝜇 ≠ 175 Calculate observed z-score: zobs = (x bar - 𝜇0) ÷ (𝜎 / √𝑛) = (162-175) ÷ (12 / √120) ≈ -11.87 Since 𝛼 = .05 and two-tailed (each tail is 0.25), look for z with area .0250: zobs = -1.96 Critical (rejection) region: Reject H0 if zobs < -1.96 (or zobs > 1.96) Since zobs < -1.96, reject H0, indicating Ohio mean (162) is significantly different from national mean (175). Same physical performance test normed nationally: 𝜇 = 175 and 𝜎 = 12. We now have a sample of n = 80 students from Colorado and found that the sample mean x bar = 177. Is it reasonable to assume that Colorado sample is drawn from the same national population? Test using 𝛼 = .05. Population 𝜇 = 175 (𝜇0), 𝜎 = 12, Colorado sample 𝑥 bar = 177, 𝑛 = 80 Nondirectional (two-tailed) so the hypotheses are: H0: 𝜇 = 175 H1: 𝜇 ≠ 175 Calculate observed z-score: zobs = (x bar - 𝜇0) ÷ (𝜎 / √𝑛) (177−175) ÷ (12 ÷ √80) ≈ 1.49 Since 𝛼 = .05 and two-tailed (each tail is .025), look for z with area .9750: 𝑧𝑐𝑟𝑖𝑡 = 1.96 Critical (rejection) region: Reject H0 if 𝑧𝑜𝑏𝑠 > 1.96 (or 𝑧𝑜𝑏𝑠< −1.96) • Since 𝑧𝑜𝑏𝑠 < 1.96, cannot reject H0, indicating Colorado sample comes from the same national norms. A high school has 49 seniors enrolled in a highly-ranked vocational program. The principal believes the mechanical ability of these seniors in the program is greater than their peers throughout the state. On a normed test of mechanical ability, the mean 𝜇 = 50 points with 𝜎 = 14 points. The sample average for the 49 seniors in the vocational program was found to be 53.4 points. At 𝛼 = .05, does the data support the principal’s claim? Population 𝜇 = 175 (𝜇0), 𝜎 = 12, our senior sample 𝑥 bar = 53.4, 𝑛 = 49 Directional (one-tailed) so the hypotheses are: H0: 𝜇 ≤ 50 H1: 𝜇 > 50 To test if sample mean is greater, stop if x bar < 𝜇0 (impossible to be greater) Calculate observed z-score: zobs = (x bar - 𝜇0) ÷ (𝜎 / √𝑛) (53.4−50) ÷ (14 ÷ √49) ≈ 1.7 Since 𝛼 = .05 and two-tailed (each tail is .025), look for z with area .9500: 𝑧𝑐𝑟𝑖𝑡 = 1.645 Critical (rejection) region: Reject H0 if 𝑧𝑜𝑏𝑠 > 1.645 Since 𝑧𝑜𝑏𝑠 > 1.645, we can reject H0 so the data support the effectiveness of the program. Notice this test would have been non-significant if it was non-directional (𝑧𝑐𝑟𝑖𝑡 = 1.96). Reject H0 if 𝜇0 falls outside of the 100 (1 - 𝛼)% confidence interval. Two-tailed: CI (x bar ± z𝛼 ÷ 2 × (𝜎 ÷ √𝑛)) does not cover 𝜇0 One-tailed: Testing if x bar is greater: LCL (x bar - z𝛼 ÷ 2 × (𝜎 ÷ √𝑛)) above 𝜇0. Testing if x bar is smaller: UCL (x bar + z𝛼 ÷ 2 × (𝜎 ÷ √𝑛)) below 𝜇0. Physical Performance in Ohio (𝜇0 = 175, σ = 12, x bar = 162, n = 120): 95% CI: x bar ± z𝛼/2 × (𝜎 ÷ √𝑛) = 162 ± 1.96 × (12/√120) = (159.853, 164.147) Since 95% CI does not cover 175, we can reject H0 (Ohio mean is significantly different from national norm) Physical Performance in Colorado (𝜇0 = 175, σ = 12, x bar = 177, n = 80) 95% CI: x bar ± z𝛼/2 × (𝜎 ÷ √𝑛) = 177 ± 1.96 × (12/√80) = (174.370, 179.630) Since 95% CI does cover 175, we cannot reject H0 (No differences detected between Colorado mean and national) Vocational Program Example (𝜇0 = 50, σ = 14, x bar = 53.4, n = 49) 95% LCL: x bar ± z𝛼/2 × (𝜎 ÷ √𝑛) = 53.4 - 1.645 × (14/√50) = 50.11(159.853, 164.147) Since 95% LCL is greater than 50, we can reject H0 (Data supports the effectiveness of the program) Probability of obtaining a test statistic at least as extreme as the one observed. Visually, it is the area more extreme (same direction of critical region) than observed statistic. Therefore, comparing p-value to 𝛼 will reach the same conclusion as comparing observed and critical statistics. Reject H0 if p-value < 𝛼 (i.e., sample stats in rejection region). 𝛼 is usually .05 (95% confidence level). Notice p-values remain the same for tests with different 𝛼 levels, but p-value from a non-directional (two-tailed) test is 2 times larger than pvalue from a directional (one-tailed) test. For extreme cases p-values can be very close to 0, but theoretically p-values cannot equal 0. Therefore, report p < .001 (NEVER report p = 0) Physical performance in Ohio: Look up 𝑧𝑜𝑏𝑠 (-11.87) on z-table, p-value is very small! Since 𝑝 < .001, reject H0 at 95% confidence level. (NEVER report 𝑝 = 0.) Physical performance in Colorado: Look up 𝑧𝑜𝑏𝑠 (1.49) on z-table, p-value = 2 × (1 − .9319) = .1362 Since 𝑝 = .1362 (𝛼 > .05), cannot reject H0 at 95% confidence level. Vocational program: Look up 𝑧𝑜𝑏𝑠 (1.70) on z-table, p-value = 1 − .9554 = .0446 Since 𝑝 = .0446 (< .05), reject H0 at 95% confidence level. Notice this test would have been non-significant if it was non-directional (𝑝 = 2 × .0446 = .0892, which would have been greater than .05). The idea is to compare sample statistics (say x bar) to the theorized distribution (say z). Reject H0 if data (zobs) shows extreme evidence (zcrit determined by 𝛼 level, usually .05). Three ways to reject H0 (one-sample z-test): The confidence interval constructed based on x bar does not cover 𝜇0. zobs > zcrit (or negative values, zobs < zcrit) p < 𝛼 (usually .05) Hypothesis testing confirms if there is a significant effect (H0 rejected), but it does not tell us how large the effect is. The effect size tells us how large the effect is (i.e., how meaningful/practical the effect). Different statistics have been developed to report effect size for different statistical analysis. For one-sample z-test (population 𝜎 known), we use Cohen's d to report effect size. Cohen's d = (x bar - 𝜇0) ÷ (𝜎) (i.e., how many SD's the difference is) Size of Cohen's d (by convention): d = ± 0.2: Small effect d = ± 0.5: Medium effect d = ± 0.8: Large effect Online Calculator:
Cohen's D Effect Size Calculator for Z-Test Physical performance in Ohio: d = (162 - 175) ÷ 12 = -1.083 (large) Physical Performance in Colorado: d = (177 - 175) ÷ 12 = 0.167 (small, recall test was non-significant) Vocational Program Example: d = (53.4 - 50) ÷ 14 = 0.243 (small) One-sample z-test is not available in SPSS menu, but there is a syntax available on YouTube by how2stats:
One sample z test - SPSS (Part1) - YouTube
One sample z test - SPSS (Part 2) - YouTube Notice the reported p-value is based on a two-tailed test. To obtain the one-tailed p-value, divide the two-tailed p-value by 2.

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 6. One-Sample T-Test, Power
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
Midterm will cover the materials from lectures 1-6: Sampling, measurement, data representation, descriptive statistics, normal distribution, z-scores, CLT, hypothesis testing, one-sample t-test, and one-sample t-test. Questions will be posted in Carmen (Assignments -> Midterm) on 6/27 (Thursday) morning. A 'homework' named 'Midterm' will open in Top Hat. Multiple choice 30 questions Work through the problems and enter your answer in Top Hat by 7/2 (Tuesday) 11:59pm. Be aware of the hard deadline. Top Hat will automatically grade your exam and publish the answers after the due date/time. No class on 7/1 (Monday) or Lab on 7/2 (Tuesday) What is Central Limit Theorem (CLT) in a nutshell? When sample size is large, sampling distribution of the mean is normal or approximately normal regardless of population distribution. How to interpret a 95% confidence interval? The interval covers the population (true) mean 95% of the time. What is a null hypothesis? Null hypothesis is saying that the intervention is not working. Says there is no statistical significance between two variables. Alternative hypothesis is the expected outcome researchers have theorized. Most of the time you want to reject the null hypothesis because there would be no statistical significance between variables (not statistically significant) What is the confidence level corresponding to a 0.05 alpha (Type I error) level? 95% Type I error is falsely rejecting the null hypothesis. It should not happen a lot. How extreme our sample mean to make it not based on chance. You can only commit Type I error 5% of the time. It only allows M P value is always between 0 and 1. If your observed z-score needs to be grater than 1.96 standard deviations above or below the mean. Comparing Type 1 Error to p-value If your p-value is greater Used for questions about whether the population mean (µ) from which we drew sample equals a specific hypothesized value (µ0). Non-directed (two-sided) or directional (one-sided) Population standard deviation (𝜎) is known. Assumptions: Observations come from a random sample, and subjects are independent of each other. Variable is measured on at least an interval level scale. Sampling distribution of the mean is normal, and CLT assures that for big samples (say 30). Used for questions about whether the population standard mean (µ) from which we drew sample equals a specific hypothesized value (µ0). Non-directional (two-sided) or directional (one-sided) Population standard deviation (𝜎) is unknown: estimated by sample standard deviation (s). Assumptions: Observations come from a random sample, and subjects are independent of each other. Variable is measured on at least an interval level scale. Sampling distribution of the mean is normal, and CLT assures that for big samples (say 30). In most research projects, population standard deviation (𝜎) are usually unknown. But we can use our sample to compute a sample standard deviation (s). So we are now estimating two population parameters: Population mean (µ) is being estimated by the sample mean (x bar). Population standard deviation (𝜎) is being estimated by the sample standard deviation (s). Recall standard error of the mean: 𝜎x bar = 𝜎 ÷ √n (𝜎 is known) Now we can estimate: 𝜎x bar = s ÷ √n. Recall for one-sample z-test: zobs = (x bar - µ0) ÷ (𝜎 ÷ √n) (𝜎 is known) Now it is estimated by: (x bar - µ0) ÷ (s ÷ √n) But is it still normally distributed? A new theoretical distribution for obtaining the critical values was developed: T-distribution (student's t-distribution) Developed by English statistician William Sealy Gosset under the pseudonym 'Student.'
Symmetric and bell-shaped like the normal distribution, but t-distribution has heavier tails (i.e., more prone to producing values that fall far from its mean). The shape of t-distribution depends on degrees of freedom (df or v). Shape of t-distribution depends on df (or sample size)
Q. What did the z-distribution say to the t-distribution? A: You may look like me but you are not normal. Non-directional (two-tailed): To test if mean where sample came from (µ) is significantly different from hypothesized mean (µ0). H0: µ = µ0 vs. H1: µ ≠ µ0 Alternatively in terms of mean difference: H0: µ - µ0 = 0 vs. H1: µ - µ0 ≠ 0 Directional (One-Tailed): H0: µ ≤ µ0 vs. H1: µ > µ0 H0: µ ≥ µ0 vs. H1: µ < µ0 Reject H0 if tobs = (x bar - µ0) ÷ (s ÷ √n) falls into the critical region (determined by tcrit given the df) A t-table might be used to determine the critical values (tcrit) and rejection region. Different t-tables might be constructed differently. For the t-tables used in class, table entries are positive t values, given specific (common) probabilities of the upper tail. (Symmetric so you can figure out negative t) Look for t value given the degrees of freedom (df = n - 1) and 𝜎 level (Area is 𝜎 ÷ 2 for two-tailed and 𝜎 for one-tailed) or confidence level (default is two-tailed) At 𝜎 = 0.05 (95% confidence level), n = 30, two-tailed test, what is the t value? From the t-table, df = 30 - 1 = 29 Upper tail is 0.025 (or 95% at the bottom) On the t-table, t = 2.045. Recall z0.025 = 1.96, which agrees that a t-distribution has heavier tails than z-distribution. Theoretically, when sample size approaches infinity (∞), t equals z. However, t-table does not have all the possible sample sizes so we rely on SPSS (p-value reported). Consider the data we collected last time sample data of the prices of OSU students are willing to pay for Gardyn (aka, willingness to pay or WTP): n = 20 (Our class is small, but your samples are usually larger) x bar = 181.9 s = 231.2 (This is bigger than the 𝜎, because we treated the class as population last time) Retail price is $899 with unknown population 𝜎 Research question: Is OSU's students' WTP (estimated by x bar) significantly different from the retail price (µ0 = 899) at 95% confidence level (i.e., should the company consider OSU students its target customers?) Average (mean) willingness to pay (WTP) is $181.9 with a standard deviation of $231.20. Skewness: 2.663 ÷ 0.512 ≈ 5.2 -> Positive Kurtosis: 8.157 ÷ 0.992 ≈ 8.2 -> Narrow


Set up hypotheses based on the research question. Where does the sample/observed mean lie on the sampling distribution? Given the confidence level 100 (1 - 𝜎)%, what is considered extreme evidence? Compared to the critical value, is the sample mean extreme enough to be considered different from µ0? Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-sample t-test Pick variable and enter the Test Value (µ0) SPSS reports p-values for both one-sided (directional) and two-sided (non-directional) tests. However, confidence interval (CI) of mean difference is only constructed for two-sided. First section: Descriptive Statistics: Check 𝜎x bar = 231.215 ÷ √20 = 51.701
Second Section: One-Sample t-test results Check t, df, and p-value
Last Section: Effect Size H0: µ = 899 or µ - 899 = 0 H1: μ ≠ 899 or μ - 899 ≠ 0 Mean difference: x bar - μ0 = 181.9 - 899 =-717.1 (Check SPSS results) tobs = (x bar - µ0) ÷ (s ÷ √n) = -717.1 ÷ 51.701 = -13.87 Degree of Freedom (df) = 20 - 1 = 19 From t-table, tcrit = -2.093 Since tobs < tcrit, we can reject the null hypothesis (H0) and conclude that OSU students' WTP for Gardyn is significantly different (lower) from the retail price. Alternatively, build a 95% confidence interval for the mean difference and reject H0 if it does not cover 0. 95% confidence interval: (x bar - µ0) ± tdf, 𝜎/2 x (s ÷ √n) -717.1 ± 2.093 x 51.701 ≈ (-825.31, -608.89) Recall last time we created a 95% CI for x bar and checked if it covered µ0. Sometimes hand-calculated numbers may have some rounding errors, but they should still be very close to the SPSS outputs. Since the 95% CI does not cover 0, we can conclude that OSU students' WTP for Gardyn is significantly different from the retail price. Finally, the easiest way: Compare p-value to α (alpha, usually .05). Reject H0 if p < α (alpha). According to SPSS (two-sided), our p-value is extremely small (p < .001). When p-value is extremely small (very close to 0), we’d report p < .001. NEVER report p = 0! Otherwise, report the observed p-value without the leading 0 (e.g., p = .003, p = .04, p = .52). •Since p < α (.05), we can reject H0 and conclude that WTP for Gardyn is significantly different from the retail price. For one-sample t-test (population σ unknown), we use Cohen’s d to report effect size. Cohen’s d = (x bar - μ0) ÷ s Recall Cohen’s d for one-sample z-test: d = (x bar - μ0) ÷ 𝜎 So, here sample SD (𝜎) is used to estimate 𝜎. Notice, unlike z or t scores, effect sizes are not affected by sample size Size of Cohen's d (by convention): Small effect: d = ± 0.2 Medium effect: d = ± 0.5 Large effect: d = ± 0.8 Cohen's d = (x bar - μ0) ÷ s = -717.1 ÷ 231.215 = -3.101 Large effect size (in reality, observing such a large effect size is highly unlikely!) SPSS also reports Hedges’s g: Cohen’s d appears to be biased for small samples (n < 20). Hedge’s g serves as an unbiased estimator of the population effect size. Hedges’s g ≈ d × {1 - (3 ÷ (4 × df - 1)} Gardyn pricing example: Hedges’s g ≈ -3.101 × {1 - (3 ÷ (4 × 19 - 1)} = -2.977
When the sample size is adequate (n = 20), we can use Cohen's d. (Your samples are usually larger.) The effect size is -3.101, indicating a large effect of the mean difference OSU students are unlikely to be Gardyn's target customers. A one-sample t-test was conducted at an alpha level of .05 to answer the research question: Is OSU students’ willingness to pay (WTP) for Gardyn significantly different from the retail price $899? The null hypothesis stated that WTP would not differ from the retail price. The alternative hypothesis stated that WTP would differ from the retail price. Based on a random sample of 20 OSU students, there was a mean WTP of $181.9 and a standard deviation of $231.215. Then compared against the hypothesized mean of $899, the one-sample t-test was statistically significant, t(19) = -13.87, p < .001, indicating WTP is significantly different from $899. In addition, the effect size Cohen’s d was -3.101, generally interpreted as a large effect (Cohen, 1988), indicating that there is about 3 standard deviations difference between WTP and retail price, with the WTP lower than the retail price. SPSS reports both one-sided and two-sided p-values, but only two-sided CI is reported. To obtain one-sided upper or lower confidence limits, run a test doubling the 𝛼 (alpha) level This doe snot affect the p-values reported in the output. Say if you are conducting a directional test a 95% confidence level and want to see LCL or UCL, you can change the confidence interval percentage from 95% to 90% in Options. The lower end of reported 90% CI would be 95% LCL (Lower Control Limit), and the upper end of reported 90% CI would be 95% (Upper Control Limit). Any variation detected inside the control limits probably occurred by chance. On the other hand, variation outside of the control limits likely occurred due to special causes. The upper control limit (UCL) and the lower control limit (LCL) serve as boundaries for expected deviation in data.

Control Charts
We wanted to test if WTP is significantly lower than retail price $899. H0: μ ≥ 899 H1: μ < 899 Can reject H0, t(19) = -3.246, p < .001 Report 95% UCL -627.7, which is below 0 so we can reject H0.
Definition: The probability that the test correctly rejects the null hypothesis when it's false (i.e., a specific alternative hypothesis is true). Power is determined by the following factors: Factors that can be controlled by the researcher: Level of significance (α): As α increases, power increases. Sample size (n): As n increases, power increases. Non-directional or directional test: Power is greater for a directional (one-tailed) test. Factors that cannot be controlled by the researcher: Size of population standard deviation (σ): As σ increases, power decreases. •Difference between true population mean (μ) and hypothesized mean (μ0): As difference increases, power increases. A priori: Determined when planning a study. Usually used to compute required sample size, given α, desired power and effect size. Completed Required Sample Size:
Post hoc (observed): Determined after a study has been conducted. Compute achieved power, given α, sample size, and observed effect size. Compute Achieved Power:
Use GPower (free software) to explore statistical power:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G*Power (Optional) SPSS: Analyze à Power Analysis When multiple hypotheses are tested (say m), the probability of observing a rare event increases, and the likelihood of incorrectly rejecting H0 (i.e., Type I error) increases. Bonferroni correction, named after Carlo Bonferroni, counteracts this problem by testing each individual hypothesis at a significance level of α ÷ m, controlling desired overall (familywise) α level. The simplest and most conservative method to control Type I error in multiple hypothesis testing. 6 t-tests were conducted (m = 6). To control the overall (familywise) α level at .05, with Bonferroni correction, each item’s p-value is now compared to the critical value α ÷ m = .05 ÷ 6 = .008. The 2nd question (p = .021) is no longer significant after Bonferroni correction. The 6th question (p = .003) remain significant. Can also create more conservative CI’s: 100 (1 - α / m)%: 99.2% CI’s are wider than 95% CI’s, making them more likely to cover the test value (μ0). One-sample z-test and one-sample t-test are considered robust for violations of normal distribution (i.e., assumption can be violated without serious errors). CLT assures that, for a large sample, the sampling distribution of the mean will be approximately normal regardless of the shape of population. However, when sample size is very small (e.g., n < 5), the test is not robust to non-normality. (Some studies also found the test is not as robust for one-tailed tests even with large samples). Non-normality can inflate the standard error of the mean, reduce power, and affect control of Type I error. Other non-parametric alternatives are available. They do not make assumptions on distribution.

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 7. Paired-Sample T-Test
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description: AKA dependent t-test: Dependent variable (DV): Scores being compared Measured on at least an interval level scale Often used to compare post-score to pre-score Independent variable (IV): The treatment or intervention Typical research question: Is there a mean difference between the post-score and pre-score? Also used to compare twins, couples, eyeballs, etc. 20 weeks of cognitive behavioral therapy -> Amount and severity of depressive symptoms Intervention -> Students' math proficiency Constraint induced movement therapy -> hand function One-group pretest-posttest design: O1 (pre) X O2 (post) One-group pretest-posttest design using a double pretest: O1 O2 X O3 One-group pretest-posttest design using a nonequivalent dependent variable: (O1A, O1B) x (O2B, O2B) The removed-treatment design: O1 x O2 (O3) x O4 The repeated-treatment design: O1 x O2 x O3 x O4 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples NR (Not Random) O1 X O2 NR (Not Random) O1 O2 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using a double pretest NR O1 O2 X O3 NR O1 O2 O3 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using switching replications NR O1 x O2 (O3) x O4 NR O1 O2 (O3) x O4 Untreated control group design dependent pretest and posttest samples using reversed-treatment control group NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) Nondirectional: Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly different from pre-score (µ1) H0: µ2 = µ1 vs. H1: µ2 ≠ µ1 Alternatively, in terms of mean difference: H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0 The mean difference is the difference in pre- and post-scores, so a paired-sample t-test is identical to a one-sample t-test, testing the difference in scores against the hypothesized (test) value! Directional: Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly greater from pre-score (µ1). H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0 Directional: Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly smaller than pre-scores (µ1): H0: µ2 - µ1 ≥ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 < 0 One Sample StatisticsOne-Sample Test For negative emotion change (hypothesized to decrease), the one-sample t-test is significant, t(33) = -2.393, p = .011. The mean difference is -0.20 (negative emotion decreased after watching the video). The 95% upper confidence limit -.0585 below zero also provides evidence that the test is significant (change significantly smaller than 0). For positive emotion change (hypothesized to increase), the one-sample t-test is significant, t(33) = 6.448, p < .001. The mean difference is 1.06 (positive emotion increased after watching the video). The 95% lower confidence limit .7809 above zero also provides evidence that the test is significant (change significantly greater than 0). tobs = d ÷ sd-bar or d ÷ (sd ÷ √n) d is the mean difference and sd-bar is the standard error of the mean difference: sd-bar = sd ÷ √n sd is the standard deviation of the difference scores (i.e., like any other standard deviation only this one is computed from the difference scores rather than raw scores). n is the total number of pairs. Recall in one-sample t-test: tobs = ( - µ0) (s ÷ √n) Where is µ0? Given 𝛼 level, nondirectional or directional, and degree of freedom (df = n - 1), critical t can be found on the t-table (if df is available). Recall rejection region is outside of critical t('s) toward the tail(s). Reject H0 if a positive tobs > tcrit (for negative values: tobs < tcrit) or p < 𝛼 (SPSS) 𝛼 level is usually .05 (95% confidence level) Nondirectional: 100 (1 - 𝛼)% CI: ± tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar ± tdf, 𝛼/2 x (sd-bar ÷ √n) To test greater (significant increase in post-scores): 100 (1 - 𝛼)% LCL: - tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar To test smaller (significant decrease in post-scores): 100 (1 - 𝛼)% UCL: + tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar DV data recorded as 2 variables (e.g., pre-score and post-score) in SPSS IV (treatment, intervention) is usually not recorded as a variable in SPSS Analyze -> Compare Means -> Paired-Samples t-test Move the two variables of interest (e.g., pre-score and post-score) to the paired variable 1 and variable 2. Notice the mean difference SPSS computes is variable 1 minus variable 2, so sometimes the sign of observed t can be confusing. However, you can easily figure out if the effect is positive or negative based on the descriptive statistics. I like to enter post-score as variable 1 and pre-score as variable 2 so I can see the change (positive or negative) from pre-score to post-score. Paired Samples StatisticsPaired Samples CorrelationsPaired Samples Test For negative emotion change: sd-bar = sd ÷ √n = .48742 ÷ √34 = .08359 tobs = d-bar ÷ sd = - .2000 ÷ .08359 = -2.393 For positive emotion change: sd-bar = sd ÷ √n = .95754 ÷ √34 = .16422 tobs = d-bar ÷ sd = 1.05882 ÷ .16422 = 6.448 Mean difference from pre- to post-score is hypothesized to decrease (one-tailed test). H0: µ2 - µ1 ≥ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 < 0 Mean difference d-bar = - .2000, SD sd = .48742, sd-bar = .08359 tobs = -2.393, df = 33, p = .011 Since the p-value (. 011) is smaller than the 𝛼 level (.05), we can reject the H0 and conclude that participants' negative emotion significantly decreased after watching the cat videos. Mean difference from pre- to post-score is hypothesized to increase (one-tailed test). H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0 Mean difference d-bar = 1.05882, SD sd = .95754, sd-bar = .16422 tobs = 6.448, df = 33, p < .001 Since the p-value is very small (< .001), we can reject the H0 and conclude that participants' positive emotion significantly increased after watching the cat videos. Cohen's d = d-bar ÷ sd-bar Recall Cohen's d for one-sample t-test: d = ( - µ0) ÷ s Size of Cohen's d (by convention): d = ±0.2: Small effect d = ±0.5: Medium effect d = ±0.8: Large effect Paired Samples Effect Sizes For negative emotion change, Cohen's d (- 0.410) suggests a small to medium effect. For positive emotion change, the effect size (d = 1.106) is quite large. The pre-video and post-video negative emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 4.80 (SD = 0.926) and a post-score mean of 4.60 (SD = 1.028). Thus, negative emotion changed by -0.20 (decrease) after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly smaller than zero (significant decrease after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly lower than the pre-score, t(33) = -2.393, p = 0.011. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size Cohen's d was -0.410. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a small to medium effect. The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the negative emotion significantly decreased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests about 0.4 standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score. The pre-video and post-video positive emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 3.76 (SD = 0.998) and a post-score mean of 4.82 (SD = 1.014). Thus, positive emotion increased by 1.06 after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly greater than zero (significant increase after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly higher than the pre-score, t(33) = 6.448, p < .001. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance. The effect size Cohen's d was 1.106. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a large effect. The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the positive emotion significantly increased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests more than one standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score. The results from the pre-test (M = 13.5, SD = 2.4) and post-test (M = 16.2, SD = 2.7) memory task indicate that the presence of caffeine in the bloodstream resulted in an improvement in memory recall, t(19) = 3.1, p = .006. There was a significant increase in the volume of alcohol consumed in the week after the end of semester (M = 8.7, SD = 3.1) compared to the week before the end of semester (M = 3.2, SD = 1.5), t(52) = 4.8, p < .001 How to Report the Result of a T-Test (APA style) If you're hypothesis testing, restate your hypothesis. If your t-test is one-tailed, you need to say so. It's preferred to report the exact p-value unless it's smaller than .001. You need to state your alpha level (usually .05) early in the results section. If your p-value is smaller than .001, it's conventional simply to state p < .001 (NEVER report p = 0) Remember to drop the leading 0 from the p-value. No need to provide a formula for observed t in your paper. Observations are from a random sample, and the scores are independent of each other. Dependent variable of interest is measured on at least an interval scale. Difference scores (d's) are normally distributed. Typically considered robust to violations of non-normality, especially for big sample (n > 30) If one of the samples is highly skewed (particularly for a one-tailed test), a lot of error will tend to be built into the difference scores. Other non-parametric analyses would be better alternatives.

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 8. Independent T-Test, Homogeneity of Variance
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
AKA two-sample t-test, independent-samples t-test or student's t-test. Dependent (DV): Scores being compared Measured on at least an interval level scale Often used to compare treatment and control groups. Independent variance (IV): The group characteristics (dichotomous) Intervention vs. No intervention Medicine vs. Placebo Typical research question: Is there a mean difference between two groups? Socioeconomic status (2 levels) Type of therapeutic intervention (2 types) -> Results of GAD-7 questionnaire over time Genre-based approach (yes/no) -> Writing skills Exposure to community violence (yes/no) -> Feelings of safety Teaching method (2 kinds) -> Students scores on the exam (TOEFL) Type of social emotional curriculum implemented in a school (2 types) -> classroom behavior, academic achievement scores Teaching style (2 types) -> reading comprehension skills of EFL middle school students Participant or non-participant in school sport -> student's cumulative grade point average. Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples NR (Not Random) O1 X O2 NR (Not Random) O1 O2 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using a double pretest NR O1 O2 X O3 NR O1 O2 O3 Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using switching replications NR O1 x O2 (O3) x O4 NR O1 O2 (O3) x O4 Untreated control group design dependent pretest and posttest samples using reversed-treatment control group NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post) Nondirectional: Test if group 1 (µ1) is significantly different from group 2 (µ2) H0: µ2 = µ1 vs. H1: µ2 ≠ µ1 Alternatively, H0: µ2 - µ1 = 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 ≠ 0 For experiment and control, usually group 1 is the experiment group. Directional: Test if group 1 (µ1) is significantly greater than group 2 (µ2): H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0 Test if group 1 (µ1) is significantly smaller than group 2 (µ2): H0: µ2 - µ1 ≥ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 < 0 tobs = (1 - 2) ÷ (sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2) 1 and 2 are the means for group 1 and group 2, respectively. sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2 is the standard error of the difference between two means, which is the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the difference between two means: sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2 = spooled √(1 ÷ n1) + (1 ÷ n2) Where spooled is the pooled standard deviation computed as spooled = √ ((n1 - 1) s12 + (n2 - 1) s22) ÷ (n1 + n2 - 2) where n1 is group 1 sample size, and n2 is group 2 sample size. Recall for paired-sample t-test: sd-bar = sd ÷ √n The observed t is then compared against the critical value from the t-table to determine a statistical decision. For independent t-test, tcrit has the degrees of freedom v = n1 + n2 - 2, at a particular level of significant 𝛼 (usually .05), for a one- or two-tailed test. Recall rejection region is outside of tcrit (s) toward the tail(s): sample data more extreme! Reject H0 if a positive tobs > tcrit (for negative values: tobs < tcrit) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < 𝛼 (SPSS output) 𝛼 level is usually .05 (95% confidence level) Make sure to report t, df, and p-value to support your conclusion. Nondirectional: 100 (1 - 𝛼)% CI: (1 - 2) ± tdf, 𝛼/2 x (sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2) Recall for paired-sample t-test: 100 (1 - 𝛼)% CI: ± tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar To test greater (treatment group is greater): 100 (1 - 𝛼)% LCL: (1 - 2) - tdf, 𝛼/2 x (sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2) To test smaller (treatment group is smaller): 100 (1 - 𝛼)% UCL: (1 - 2) + tdf, 𝛼/2 x (sx-bar 1 - sx-bar 2) Group 1: City (n1 = 26) Mean: 55.23 SD: 19.371 Variance: 375.225 Group 2: Country (n2 = 22) Country (n2 = 22) Mean: 62.73 SD: 17.236 Variance: 297.065 Exploratory in nature (non-directional) and no treatment/control groups Research Question: Do people living in the city and in the country spend differently (spending) on July 4th fireworks? Group 1: City (n1 = 26) Group 2: Country (n2 = 22) Group 1 (Experiment): Mobile (n1 = 22) Mean: 1.2927 SD: 0.24631 Variance: 0.061 Group 2 (Control): In-Person (n2 = 31) Mean: 1.4839 SD: 0.40342 Variance: 0.163 Don't be confused with variable coding. In my SPSS file, variable order is coded as 1 = In-Person and 2 = Mobile
Research Question: Are burritos ordered (order) in-person significantly bigger (weight) than the ones via mobile orders? Group 1: Mobile (n1 = 22) Group 2: In-Person (n2 = 31) Since the research interest is if mobile orders are smaller, I'll treat the mobile group as experiment (group 1 in SPSS for independent t-test) and in-person as control (group 2 in SPSS for independence t-test). Don't be confused with variable coding. For the variable order, value 1 = In-Person and value 2 = Mobile (nominal coding is interchangeable) DV is usually recorded as one variable. IV is usually recorded as another variable to identify groups (dichotomous, or pick 2 groups at a time to compare). Analyze -> Compare Means -> Independent-Samples t-test Move DV to Test Variable(s) Move IV to Grouping Variable and define groups (Group 1 and Group 2) If there are treatment and control groups, group 1 is usually treatment and group 2 is control. The mean difference is group 1 minus group 2. You can refer to the descriptive statistics to confirm which group is higher. AKA homoscedasticity When comparing means, we need the dispersion to be similar in both groups. The distortion in spread can interfere with our investigation of difference between means. HOV assumes population variances for the two groups are equal. If design is balanced (n1 = n2), no need to worry about departure from HOV (independent t-test is robust in this case). HOV tests are sensitive to violations of other assumptions about the data, especially normality. So there are many versions of this test: An easy way (by hand) is the F-max test (aka Hartley's F-max test). SPSS uses Levene's HOV test for independent t-test. This is the first time we do not reject the null hypothesis. F has two degrees of freedom H0: 𝜎12 = 𝜎22 vs. H0: 𝜎12 ≠ 𝜎22 Or alternatively, H0: 𝜎12 ÷ 𝜎22 = 1 vs. H0: 𝜎12 ÷ 𝜎22 ≠ 1 (whether the ratio of 2 variances equals 1) For convenience we generally put the larger variance in the numerator and smaller variance in the denominator, and the ratio follows an F-distribution: Fmax = (s2) (larger) ÷ (s2) (smaller) Fmax is compared to a critical F value. For this test, we hope to retain (cannot reject) H0 so HOV is tenable (satisfactory)! Small Fmax or big p-value are good (i.e., equal variances)!

The F distribution is usually used to compare variances. Since variances are always a squared value and always non-negative, the F statistic does not go below 0, and it is not symmetric. The F-statistics has two sets of degrees of freedom: Numerator (v1) and denominator (v2). The pair of degrees of freedom determine the shape of the F distribution. When comparing two groups (sample sizes n1 and n2), v1 = n1 - 1 and ), v2 = n2 -1. If F-max test, v1 (dfnum) is the degree of freedom for group with larger variance, and v2 (dfdenom) is the degree of freedom for the group with smaller variance. Reject H0 if Fmax ≥ F (α, dfnum, dfdenom) but we don't want to reject it! Fmax = 375.225 ÷ 297.065 ≈ 1.263 Critical F (. 05, 25, 21) = 2.045 Since 1.263 < 2.045, cannot reject H0 Fireworks spending for people living in the city has a variance comparable to that of in the country (HOV satisfactory)! H0: 𝜎12 = 𝜎22 = ... = 𝜎k2 vs. H1: At least 2 group variances are different (k = 2 for our purpose) [Optional] Test statistics Fobs Total sample size n divided into k groups (j = 1, 2, ..., k); We are just comparing 2 groups (k = 2) Sample size for each group is n1, n2, ..., nj, ..., nk i denotes the ith subject (data point) in group j zij = | xij - xj | is the absolute deviation from a data point to jth group mean Brown and Forsythe extended this to median or 10% trimmed mean Numerator: Between group variation (in terms of absolute deviation) Denominator: Within group variation (in terms of absolute deviation) We would reject H0 if Fobs > Fk - 1, n - k (here k = 2) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < .05 Since we want to find no statistically significant difference in variances between the two groups, a p ≥ .05 (big p-value) is desired here! We will let SPSS do Levene's HOV test for us! Just remember if we see a big p-value (p-value ≥ .05), HOV is tenable (satisfactory). If p-value is small (p < .05), HOV is violated. The Welch's t-test (aka separate variances t-test, unequal variances t-test) is usually appropriate when the population variances are unequal and the sample sizes are unequal. [Optional] tobs = unstandardized b ÷ standard error Variance errors of the mean are computed for each group where s12 are sample variances for groups. The criteria to reject H0 are the same as independent t-test (extreme t or small p). We'll let SPSS do Welch's t-test for us! Just remember if we see a small p-value (p < .05), we can reject H0 and claim difference between the two group means is significantly different from 0 (or one-sided p-value to test greater/smaller). Make sure to report t, df, and p-value to support your conclusion.

First check HOV assumption: Satisfactory, F (1, 46) = 0.519, p = .475 (i.e., cannot reject H0 equal variance), so we can use independent t-test results from the first line (equal variances assumed). We are not trying to compute the observed F for Levene's Test, but the df is (k - 1, n - 2) = (1, 46). spooled = √(25 x 375.225 x 21 x 297.065) ÷ (46) = 18.4267 sx-bar 1 - x-bar 2 = 18.4267 √(1 ÷ 26) + (1 ÷ 22) = 5.3379 tobs = (-7.497) ÷ (5.3379) ≈ -1.404 df = n1 + n2 -2 = 26 + 22 - 2 = 46 Since p-value (make sure we look at results from the first line) is quite large (p = .167), we cannot reject H0 -> Spending on fireworks did not differ significantly between people living in the city (M = 55.23, SD = 19.371) and the country (M = 62.73, SD = 17.236), t(46) = -1.404, p = .167. Notice 95% CI (-18.241, 3.248) also covers 0, agreeing with the non-significant t-test.

First check HOV assumption. Violated, F (1, 51) = 9.594, p = .003 (i.e., reject H0 equal variance), so we are using the results (Welch's t-test aka separate variances t-test) from the second line (equal variances not assumed). For Welch's t-test, it is difficult to calculate the degree of freedom (50.061) by hand. A one-tailed t-test was conducted (if mobile orders are significantly smaller than in-person orders). Since the p-value (make sure we look at results from the second line) < .05 (p = .019), we can reject H0 -> Mobile-Ordered Burritos (M = 1.29, SD = 0.246) are significantly smaller than burritos ordered in-person (M = 1.48, SD = 0.403), t(50.061) = -2.136, p = .019. Notice the 95% upper confidence limit (-0.04118) is below 0, agreeing with the significant t-test results. Cohen's d = (1 - 2) ÷ spooled Size of Cohen's d (by convention): d = ±0.2: Small effect d = ±0.5: Medium effect d = ±0.8: Large effect Use Cohen's d when HOV is satisfactory and sample size is large (total n at least 40 or 50) Hedges' g ≈ (1 - 2) ÷ spooled (1 - 3 ÷ 4n - 9) Total sample size n = n1 + n2 Provides a bias correction to Cohen's d for small sample sizes Uses Hedges' g when HOV is satisfactory and sample size is small (n < 40 or 50) Glass's Delta (∆) = (1 - 2) ÷ spooled Uses only the control group's (group 2 in SPSS) standard deviation Use Glass's delta when HOV is violated (variances significantly different between groups) Use the same convention as Cohen's d to interpret Hedge's g or Glass's delta.
Since HOV is satisfactory and sample size is fairly large (n = 48), it's appropriate to use Cohen's d (-0.407) and Hedges' g (-0.400) effect size measures. Both indicate small effect size. Notice the standardizer (denominator) for Cohen's d is the same as the pooled standard deviation we calculated (spooled = 18.427). APA Style Writing Template: An independent t-test was conducted to determine if people living in the city spend differently on July 4 th fireworks compared to those in the country. Data on spending was gathered from samples of 26 city dwellers and 22 country folks. The sample mean for the city was $62.73 (SD = 17.236).
Levene's test for homogeneity of variance confirmed the assumption, F (1, 46) = 0.519, p = .475. The independent t-test indicated that the spending means were not significantly different for people in the city and country, t (46) = -1.404, p = .167. We failed to reject the null hypothesis that the spending was the same between locations at the .05 level of significance. Therefore, we can conclude that location is not significant factor in determining firework spending. Cohen's d was -0.407, suggesting a small effect size.
Since HOV is violated, we can use Glass's delta (-0.474) to measure effect size (in-person as control group), which indicates a small to medium effect size. Notice the standardizer (denominator) for Glass's delta is the standard deviation from the in-person (control group or group 2 in SPSS) (0.40342) APA Style Writing Template We wanted to determine if burritos ordered via mobile app are significantly smaller than burritos ordered in person. From a random sample, we weighed 22 burritos placed via mobile orders (M = 1.29, SD = 0.246) and 31 ordered in-person (M = 1.48, SD = 0.403).
According to Levene's test, the homogeneity of variance assumption was violated, F (1, 51) = 9.594, p = .003. Therefore, a separate variances t-test was conducted. The t-test result was significant at the .05 confidence level, t (50.061) = -2.136, p = .019. We can conclude that mobile-ordered burritos are significantly smaller than in-person orders. Glass's delta was -0.474, suggesting a small to medium effect size. Measure or characteristic is normally distributed in each of the two populations (i.e., the two groups). Observations are from a random sample, and the scores in each sample (people) are independent of each other. DV is measured on at least an interval level scale. HOV (homogeneity of variance): The variances in the two populations are comparable. If violated (and design is not balanced), use Welch's t-test (separate variances t-test) instead. Is vitamin C effective to treat colds? A health-researcher recruited a sample of 27 adults and followed them for a year to assess the number of colds they had in year 1. She then had them take weekly doses of vitamin C and followed them in year 2. Paired because it is a pre to post. A social studies teacher wanted to determine if the students in his school in the US have similar perceptions of world leaders compared to other countries. Where leaders are rated from 0 (worthless) to 10 (effective), the global norm on the 'World Leader Scale' is 6 with a standard deviation of 1.8. The teacher took a sample of 35 students from the school and had them fill out the same WLS. One sample z-test A counseling psychologist wanted to determine if prisoners who are depressed eat less of their meals than prisoners who are not depressed. There were 130 prisoners who volunteered for the study, and 42 of them were classified as depressed. The psychologist monitored the amount of each meal in ounces eaten by both groups for a week. Independent t-test A random sample of 39 museum visitors were questioned on how much they spend per month on cultural or arts-related events. The survey found that, on average, these visitors spent $40 per month with a standard deviation of $12. The researcher wanted to test whether the monthly expenditure for museum visitors is below $45. One sample t-test

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 9. Test for Correlation, Simple Linear Regression (SLR)
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
We already know many ways to represent the association between two variables, both measured on at least an interval scale. Scatterplot Covariance sxy = (∑i = 1n (x1 - x-bar)(yi - y-bar)) ÷ n - 1 (𝜎xy for population) Pearson correlation coefficient rxy = (sxy) ÷ (sxsy) (𝜌xy for population) The correlation reflects the noisiness and direction of a linear relationship, but not the slope of that relationship, nor many aspects of non-linear relationships. To test whether the sample correlation between x and y is significantly different from zero (non-directional): H0: 𝜌 = 0 vs. H1: 𝜌 ≠ 0 Directional alternatives are also possible. Assumptions:
Linearity The Pearson correlation assumes that the relationship among x and y is a linear relationship. Independence: Units or cases are randomly sampled from the population. tobs = r√(n - 2) ÷ (1 - r2) tcrit: Given the 𝛼 level, t distribution with degrees of freedom (df = n - 2) Reject H0 if tobs > tcrit (or for negative values: tobs < tcrit) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < 𝛼 APA Style Writing Template: A Pearson correlation coefficient was computed to assess the linear relationship between x and y. There was a (weak / moderate / strong negative / positive) correlation between x and y, r (df) = (p-value). Notice: No need to report t. tobs = r√(n - 2) ÷ (1 - r2) = (. 698)√ (858 - 2) ÷ (1 - .698)2) ≈ 28.52 df = n - 2 = 858 - 2 = 856 (Optional) At 𝛼 = .05, tcrit = 1.963 -> Since tobs > tcrit, reject H0 From SPSS, p-value < .001 -> Reject H0 APA Style Writing Template: There was a strong positive correlation between GPA and ACT, r (856) = .598, p < .001. (Optional) Online calculators also available (section 3):
Online-Calculator for testing correlations: Psychometrica Restricting the range of scores on one or both variables will reduce the strength of a correlation. If the size of the standard deviation for one variable is reduced, everything else being equal, then the size of correlations with other variables will also be reduced. In other words, we need sufficient variation for a relationship to be evidenced through the correlation coefficient value. HS GPA and ACT example: The strength of correlation between GPA and ACT will be lessened if we only focus on the graduates with summa cum laude (weighted GPA 4.2 or above). Correlation means the variables are related in some way, but correlations alone should not be used to infer cause. A high correlation between x and y might be a result of: x causes y y causes x A third variable z is causing both x and y (or even more variables are involved). Causality is not easy to prove. Application of complex statistical methods is not evidence for causality! Causation (x -> y) can only be inferred (formalized by the 19th-century philosopher John Stuart Mill) if: x proceeded y x was related to y We can find no other plausible alternative explanation for the effect on y other than x. Say we have data from 2 independent samples. We want to determine if the correlations between x and y are equal for these 2 independent samples. For example, is the correlation between GPA and ACT the same for Happy Valley HS (r = .654) and for Eureka HS (r = .765)? Happy Valley HS: r = .654 n = 155 Eureka HS: r = .765 n = 188 Hypotheses (Non-Directional): H0: 𝜌1 - 𝜌2 = 0 vs. H1: 𝜌1 - 𝜌2 ≠ 0 Directional alternatives are also possible. Ranges of r is restricted so we use Fisher transformation to transform r1 and r2 to z1 and z2 respectively:
Fisher transformation - Wikipedia z = (1/2) ln ((1+r) ÷ (1-r)) = artanh (r) 'ln' is the natural logarithm function 'artanh' is the inverse hyperbolic tangent function Online calculators available (section 6):
Online-Calculator for testing correlations: Psychometrica zobs = (z1 - z2) ÷ (√ (1 ÷ n1 - 3) + (1 ÷ n2 - 3)) zcrit: Find the critical z given the 𝛼 level (e.g., ± 1.96 at 𝛼 = .05) Reject H0 if zobs > zcrit (or zobs < zcrit for negative values) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < 𝛼 No SPSS procedure, but syntax and other online calculators available (section 1):
Online-Calculator for testing correlations: Psychometrica This calculator is one-tailed though! You can multiply by 2 for a two-tailed test. Happy Valley HS (r1 = .654, n1 = 155): z1 = (1/2) ln ((1 + .654) ÷ (1 - .654)) = .782 Eureka HS (r2 = .765, n2 = 188): z2 = (1/2) ln ((1 + .765) ÷ (1 - .765)) = 1.008 zobs = (z1 - z2) ÷ (√ (1 ÷ n1 - 3) + (1 ÷ n2 - 3)) = (. 782 - 1.008) ÷ (√ (1 ÷ 152) + (1 ÷ 185)) = -2.064 (More extreme than -1.96) Can get p-value from z-table, Excel, or double the online calculator p-value (one-tailed) Reject H0 and conclude that the correlation between GPA and ACT for Happy Valley (r = .654) is significantly different from the correlation for Eureka HS (r = .765), z = -2.064, p = .04. 'Ballpark' estimates for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ± .2 (weak) r = ± .4 (moderate) r = ± .8 (strong) It also depends on the nature of variables, studies, and fields (literature review). Cohen's (1988) standards for Pearson correlation coefficient r: r = ± .1 (weak) r = ± .3 (moderate) r = ± .5 (strong) Correlation does not imply causation. With proper literature review and research design, however we can investigate how one variable (x or IV) explains the variability (variance) in the other variable (y or DV). If x is indeed a significant predictor of y, we can use x to predict y. Still a bivariate analysis, but with a different goal in mind. For example, the school district might want to use GPA to explain the variable in ACT scores and use GPA to predict ACT.
Here we have only one predictor (IV) in the model: Simple Linear Regression (SLR). You will learn regression models with multiple predictors, multiple linear regression (MLR), in more advanced stats classes. Regression means you are trying to find a pattern between x and y. You are using x to predict y. We are only using one.
If we square the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) between x and y, r2 indicates the proportion of the Variance in y that can be explained by x. HS GPA and ACT example: r = .698 Square it: r2 = (. 698)2 ≈ .487 This indicates 48.7% of the variance in ACT scores can be explained (or accounted for) by GPA. Recall r ranges from -1 to 1. What does it mean for the range of r2? Recall 'ballpark' effect size: Weak (|r| ≥ .2) Weak (r2 ≥ .04 or 4%) Moderate (|r| ≥ .4) Moderate (r2 ≥ .16 or 16%) Strong (|r| ≥ .8) Strong (r2 ≥ .64 or 64%) ACES (Adverse Childhood Experiences) -> Psychological symptoms Word exposure frequency and elaboration of word processing in incidental vocab learning -> incidental vocabulary acquisition and rentention through extensive reading The user's tech literacy or tech-savviness, overall product quality (design, build, execution, etc.), and many more -> User experience or user satisfaction of an EdTech product Student's participation -> Student's sense of belonging Grade point average -> Success in first year of college xi: IV data point for subject i yi: DV data point for subject i yi: Expected/predicted value for subject i (i.e., the regression line)
𝛽0: Intercept (Constant) 𝛽1: Slope (How much DV increases as IV increases by 1 unit) One statistician movie fan decided to use statistics to study the movie ratings in his favorite movie guide, Movie and Video Guide (1996), by Leonard Maltin. Maltin rates movies on a one-star to four-star system, in increments of half-stars, with higher numbers being better. The guide also includes additional information on each film. The statistician used a random number generator to select a simple random sample of 100 movies rated by the Guide. Rating: Maltin rating (range is 1 to 4, in steps of 0.5) Length: Running time (in minutes) Year: Year the movie was released Cast: Number of case members listed in the guide Origin: Country (0 = USA, 1 = International) Finding b0 and b1 (regression coefficients) for the regression line:
Best estimates for b's are the ones that provide minimal error over any other collection of b's. Working with the squared values, our goal is to find estimate b0 and b1 to minimize the error sum of squares: SSE = The optimal solution: b0 = y-hat - b1x-bar Regression line goes through both means of x and y! The slope is determined by the correlation between x and y with a scale of y per change in x. Analyze -> Regression -> Linear Define DV and IV (one IV for SLR) Usually you'd already review descriptive statistics and correlations before running a regression, but you can also ask SPSS to report Descriptive in the Statistics option. Many other options are for MLR only. The default SPSS output has 3 sections: Model Summary (How much variance in DV is explained by the model) ANOVA Table (Model significance) Regression Coefficients (Equation for the regression line) Total variability (variance) in DV is partitioned into two parts: What we can explain by the model (regression) What we still cannot explain (error) Regression sum of squares (SSR) Error Sum of Squares (SSE) Total Sum of Squares (SSTO) SSTO = SSR + SSE SSR, SSE, and SSTO are available in the ANOVA table R2 indicates the proportion of variance in DV explained (accounted for) by the model, which can be considered the overall model fit. R2 = (SSR) ÷ (SSTO) = 1 - (SSE ÷ SSTO) = (Multiple R)2 In SLR, R2 equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y Multiple R is the correlation between yi and y-hati (always positive) In SLR, Multiple R = | rxy |
Recall Pearson r = .318 (weak to moderate positive) Multiple R = .318 (weak to moderate relationship) R2 = .101, indicating 10.1% of variance in movie rating can be explained by running time.
Recall Pearson r = -.148 (weak negative) Multiple R = .148 (weak relationship) R2 = .022, indicating only 2.2% of variance in movie rating can be explained by the year a movie was released. Omnibus: Comprising several items "Congress passed an omnibus anticrime package." The omnibus test is used to evaluate the significance of overall regression model. Statistics used to conduct the omnibus test are available in the ANOVA table. Many different (equivalent) ways to represent the omnibus test, but they are asking the same question: Is the regression model good enough to be used to explain/predict DV? Since we are comparing variances (SSR and SSE), the sample statistics is compared to a critical F statistics, given the significance level (usually α=.05). General idea: Large observed F means much variance in DV can be explained by the model (desired)! H0: β1 = 0 H1: β1 ≠ 0 H0: y-hat = y-bar H1: y-hat = b0 +b1x (DV cannot be predicted by model) H0: ρ = 0 (ρ is the population correlation between model and data, estimated by Multiple R) H1: ρ > 0 H0: ρ2 = 0 H1: ρ2 > 0 Compare Fobs to the critical F(1, n -2) Reject H0 if Fobs > F(1, n -2) Alternatively, reject H0 if p < α For APA style writing, make sure you report the F statistic along with both degrees of freedom and the p-value.
SSR = 4.918 SSE = 43.609 Fobs = MSR / MSE = (SSR / 1) / (SSE / n - 2) = (4.918 / 1) / (43.609 / 98) = 11.052 Since p = .001, reject H0 (significant model/predictor) Report F (1, 98) = 11.052, p = .001 Can also check R2 = (SSR) / (SSTO) = 4.918 / 48.528 = .101
SSR = 1.057 SSE = 47.471 Fobs = MSR / MSE = (SSR / 1) / (SSE / n - 2) = (1.057 / 1) / (47.471 / 98) = 2.182 Since p = .143, cannot reject H0 (model/predictor not significant) Report F (1, 98) = 2.182, p = .143 Can also check R2 = (SSR) / (SSTO) = 1.057 / 48.528 = .022

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: ANOVA APA Write-Up Example
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description: A one-way ANOVA was used to assess the effect of a mindfulness intervention on students’ anxiety. It was predicted that students’ anxiety scores would differ based on whether students were in the mindfulness intervention group (mindfulness) or the business as usual group (BAU). We first checked the normality of our data by calculating the skewness and kurtosis, visually examining histograms, and running Shapiro-Wilk’s test. The assumption of normality was upheld for both groups. The Shapiro-Wilk’s test was non-significant for both the mindfulness group, W(18) = .93, p = .17, and BAU group, W(18) = .94, p = .27. The skewness and kurtosis values were within acceptable rant for the mindfulness group (skewness = -0.10, kurtosis = -1.45) and the BAU group (skewness = 0.03, kurtosis = -1.34). Additionally, the assumption of homogeneity of variance was upheld by a non-significant Levene’s test (F(1, 34) = .61, p = .44), indicating that equal variances are assumed. The one-way ANOVA reached significance, F(1, 34) = 54.82, p < .001, η2 = .62. Given the significantly observed difference and effect size, our results support the conclusion that students’ anxiety score varied significantly based on their group.

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 1. Introduction and Fundamentals
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
Behavioral and social scientists describe phenomena like drug use, psychiatric distress, and academic achievement using parametric statistical models. Common methods include analyzing Central Tendencies, Score Variations, and associations between characteristics. Behavioral and social scientists learn about phenomena by understanding how variables relate to each other. To grasp these relationships, we ask three fundamental questions: Are two variables related? What is the direction of their relationship? How strong is the relationship? Statistical Models = 𝛽0 + 𝛽1X1 + 𝛽2X2 + 𝛽3X3 Y: Dependent (outcome) variable : predicted score of Y Y - : Error Measuring Model Error Use subscript i to indicate the subject, e.g., e1 = Y1 - 1, e2 = Y2 - 2 ... Square each individual's error and sum them all:
Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) SSE measures the model's basic error. The goal of statistical modeling is to make small changes to improve the model. Test if the new model reduces error (smaller SSE) compared to the previous model. If a more complex model predicts Y better (lower SSE), we conclude the added complexity (new predictor X) improved the model. The general linear model (GLM) is a way to simplify and combine multiple linear regression models into a single, unified format. It is not a different type of model but a more efficient way to represent them. General form: Y = XB + U Data = Model + Error The key word is 'general.' The GLM can be used to make predictions from various models. Depending on the outcome variable, logistic regression, ordinal regression, or count models (Poisson) may be used - these are also forms of the GLM. Another term: Generalized Linear Models (GLIM) The GLM is actually a special case of (GLIM)! Types of Data
Binary
Nominal (Categorical)
Ordinal
Frequencies
Continuous
Pseudo-Continuous
Parameter
Predictor s, independent variables (x)
Outcome s, dependent variables (y) Factors, levels, groups
Mean The sum of all scores divided by the number of scores.
Median The middle score in a set of data that has been arranged in numerical order. If there are an even number of scores, you find the average between the two middle most scores.
Mode The most frequent score in the dataset.
Range The difference between the maximum score and the minimum score.
Variance A measure of the spread of the data around the mean.

Standard Deviation (SD) Also measures the spread of the data around the mean The square root of the variance. Shows how different the population mean is likely to be from the sample mean. 𝜎x = 𝜎 ÷ √*n Exact, uses the population standard deviation, which is usually unknown. Sx-bar = S ÷ √*n Estimate, uses the sample standard deviation, which is known. Skewness is a measure of symmetry or asymmetry of data distribution. Kurtosis measures whether data is heavy-tailed or light-tailed in a distribution. Considered normal if within +/- 2



Mean =AVERAGE (First cell, Last cell)
Median =MEDIAN (First cell, Last cell)
Mode =MODE (First cell, Last cell) Minimum =MIN (First cell, Last cell) Maximum =MAX (First cell, Last cell)
Skewness =SKEW (First cell, Last cell)
Kurtosis =KURT (First cell, Last cell)

Calculate the Mean =AVERAGE (First cell, Last cell) Calculate the Deviation = Data cell - Mean cell Square the Deviation =E 2^2
Calculate the Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) (Square Deviations) =SUM (First cell, Last cell) Input the Degrees of Freedom DF = n - 1 Calculate the Variance =SS / DF Calculate the Standard Deviation √(Variance) =SQRT (Cell) Calculate the Standard Error = Standard Deviation / √(n) =F 21 / (SQRT (15))
