university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 2. Predicting Scores (Mean and Error of Prediction)
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
Understand what the data, model, and error are in GLM framework. Understand how to quantify the ERROR: Learn how to compute the Sum of Squares of Error (SSE)
How to compute the variance and standard deviation (Standard Deviation (SD)) Use Excel to compute the SSE Hypothesis testing for a simple t-test
Data: Values derived from scientific experiments Data can refer to countless variables, scores, and sources of information To understand a phenomenon, a behavioral scientist must first operationally define it as a measurable variable. Common descriptive statistics are the mean and standard deviation. Prediction is one way to demonstrate understanding of something. A model that predicts a phenomenon well implies that we understand that phenomenon. An initial model that predicts the mean for every subject serves as the foundation on which subsequent models are based. Y = 𝛽0 + 𝜀 (Simplest model that we use) The single predictive component of the model () is designated as 𝛽0. Comparing the actual scores (Y) and the predicted scores reveals how much error exists in this simple model. Rarely would all of the scores on the dependent variable equal the mean. We study the error in our model in hopes that we can reduce the error to improve our model. To reduce the error, we must be able to measure error.
Conceptual Formula SSE = ∑ (Yi - Y-Hati)2 It captures the concept of error by squaring and summing the differences between predicted and actual scores. It is a bit clumsy, especially when the mean is not an integer.
Computational Formula SSE = ∑Y2 - (∑Y)2 / N) This is more convenient to compute SSE compared to the conceptual formula. Variance (S2) and standard deviation (S) describe the variation of scores around a mean. Variance is SSE divided by the number of scores minus 1: SSE / (N - 1) Variance = Sy2 = (∑Y2 - (∑Y)2 / N)) / (N - 1) Since we squared the variable's scores to make them positive, we take the square root of the variance to return to the variable's score to return to the variable's origina; scale. The square root of the variance is called the standard deviation (S) We want to know whether the mean is statistically significantly different from 0. We use the one-sample t-test to examine whether μ = 0 Hypothesis testing is a decision-making process where two-possible decisions are considered. H0 (Null or Statistical Hypothesis) H1 (Alternative or Research Hypothesis) Definition
A method for testing a hypothesis about a Parameter or Population, using data measured in a sample. Purpose
To test claims or ideas about a group or Population. Goal
To determine the likelihood that a Population Parameter, such as the Mean, is likely to be true. Four Steps of hypothesis testing State the null and alternative hypothesis
Null Hypothesis (H0) Statement about the population parameter that is assumed to be true. Center orange line. H0 = 3 Alternative Hypothesis (H1) Statement that contradicts the null hypothesis. Circled tails. H1 ≠ 3 Set the criteria for a decision State the level of significance Criterion of judgement upon which a decision is made regarding the value stated in a null hypothesis. Typically the level is set at 5% in behavioral research studies. Compute the test statistic Test statistic Z-score How far a sample outcome is from the value stated in a null hypothesis z = (x - M) / SD zobt = (M - μ) / σM The z-score can be used to make a decision regarding the null hypothesis. The larger the value, the further a sample mean deviates from the population mean. T-score tobt = (M - μ) / σM Make a decision Based on the probability of obtaining a sample mean, given that the value stated in the null is true (represented by p-value). Reject H0 The sample mean is associated with a low probability of occurrence. Retain (fail to reject) H0 The sample mean is associated with a high probability of occurrence. Statistical significance If z-statistic falls within 2 SE of M, sample mean is 'normal' (p > 0.05) If z-statistic falls outside 2 SE of M, sample mean is 'extreme' (p < 0.05)
You need 3 pieces of information to use the t-table Sample size α-level One-tailed or two-tailed? Reading a t-table is different from reading a z-table. You calculate t-value from your data and find the critical t-value from the table. If the calculated t is greater than the critical t, you reject the H0.
Data The phenomenon being studied must be defined as a measurable variable.
Model The part that predicts the phenomenon.
Error Shows how different the prediction is from the true value. Y = 𝛽0 + 𝜀 Other terms such as 'the simple model' or the 'null model' We add predictors (or independent variables) to improve the accuracy of the model - by reducing the error. When we reduce the error, our model improves. We started calculating error using the computational formula last week.
We use the error (by calculating SSE or Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) to calculate the Variance and Standard Deviation (SD).
State the null and alternative hypotheses On average, students who took intro statistics report that they are somewhat confident in their statistic abilities. H0: M = 5 Students in the GLM class will report that they are less than somewhat confident in their statistics abilities. H1 M < 5
Set the criteria for a decision ⍺ = .05 (95% CI) Compute the test statistic
Make a decision
t-critical value (look up with Degrees of Freedom and T-Table for one-tailed test) 1.697 | -3.857 | > 1.697 Decision Fail to reject the null hypothesis Specifying the direction (positive/negative, greater/lesser, etc.) during hypothesis testing Non-Directional
Example Is there a mean difference in motivation scores between students in a persistence-based curriculum as compared to the control curriculum? H0: µpersistence motivation = µcontrol motivation H1: µ persistence motivation ≠ µcontrol motivation Directional:
Example Do students in a persistence-based curriculum report higher mean motivation scores than those in a control curriculum? H0: µpersistence motivation = µcontrol motivation H1: µ persistence motivation > µcontrol motivation 'Fail to reject the null' vs. 'Confirm [accept/support] the null' 'Fail to reject the null' Cons Double-negative, an editor at the communications will tell you that this is badly written, but there is a technical difference which matters. We are not determining whether we accept/confirm/support, but we are determining whether we reject the null. Pros Statistically accurate. Tip: Avoid using terms like 'confirm' (alternative: results provide support for the alternative hypothesis) Null Findings Pros Important for being good stewards of numbers to make inferences about people. Cons Bad for your academic career What is 'Significant'? Beware of terms like 'approaching significance' .05 - this is a kind of arbitrary number Don't remember the syntax? Start with the point & click method and use the paste button. Save templates/examples to reference in the future. For specific projects, use annotations to: Keep track of data management procedures Check your work for mistakes Revisit analysis (what did I do again?), replicate analysis, or revise analysis (oh, I forgot to do this...)

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: 3. Bivariate Regression
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
Understand the bivariate regression in terms of the amount of error and the regression coefficients. Learn how to calculate the intercept (b0) and slope (b1) of bivariate regression using Excel and SPSS. Learn how to compute the Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) for compact and augmented models. Effect size computation by comparing the sum of squared total (SST) and SSE The simple model (i.e., mean-only model) is not very informative and has a lot of error. Y = 𝛽0 + 𝜀 Our model-building goal is to improve prediction and thereby reduce the error. To improve prediction and reduce error, we add a predictor variable (X) to the model. This enhanced model is the beginning of a 'predictive formula' that predicts individual outcome variable scores (Y) better than just predicting the mean. To use a bivariate regression model, identify two types of variables:
Predictor, or known variable (x)
Outcome, or to-be-predicted variable (y) Regression analysis provides an equation that corresponds to a line that best predicts y scores from x scores.
The model Population Parameter will be designated with a Greek letter (β). The estimate of the population parameter, which we calculate using our sample data, is designated by the Arabic letter b. We can predict a person's score on an outcome (dependent) variable (Y-Hat) based on what we know about that person's score on a predictor (independent) variable (x). If variables x and y are related to each other, then adding x to our model improves prediction and produces less error (SSE) than the simple model generated. Here we have two competing models: You can use bivariate regression to answer the following questions about the pattern of data points and the significance of a linear equation: Is a pattern evident in a set of data points? Which equation of a straight line can best describe this pattern? Are the predictions made from this equation significant? More questions using Bivariate Regression: What is the nature of the relation between x and y? Is b statistically significant? What is the Confidence Interval for b. What is the effect size? How is the y variance partitioned between explained and unexplained? Do plots of residuals indicate violations of assumptions for bivariate linear regression? The error produced by Model C is the most error a parametric model can have. Thus, we often call this model as the simplest or null model.
We call the sum of squared errors generated by Model C the Sum of Squares Total (SST). We call the sum of squared errors by Model A SSEA. SST is almost always greater than SSEA. SST = SSEA + SSR Y-Hat = b0 + b1X Y-Hat: Predicted value of Y b0: Intercept, the value of Y when X = 0. b1: Slope, the change in Y relative to the change in X. We actually never know the true population value of parameter β; we only estimate with our data. Yi = 𝛽0 + 𝛽1Xi + 𝜀i We will calculate b1 first. Determine b0 and using b1. Conceptual Formula
Computational Formula



To estimate the error generated by this augmented model (SSEA) we need to Predict a score on Y for each subject. Find the difference between each subject's predicted and actual scores on Y. Square the differences. Add them up. Y = 10.268 - .776x + 𝜀
It is difficult to judge is an error reduction of 64.383 is a lot or a little. To help us get a sense of how much error we reduced, we express this reduction in error as a percentage of the total error (SST). The regression model explained .805 (80.5%, effect size) of the original SST in variable Y.

For the simple mean-only model, 𝛽0, was a constant equal to the mean of Y. Since the mean of Y was 6, 𝛽0 = 6. The intercept, 𝛽0, is the predicted value of Y when X is zero. Thus, if X has no meaningful value of 0, the estimated intercept is not informative. Centering the predictor of X to its mean can generate a better estimate because then the estimated 𝛽0 is now the predictor value of Y when the predictor X is its mean. Think about the 1st year college CPA as the outcome (Y) predicted by the SAT score (X).

Y = 10.268 - .776 X + 𝜀 Y = 6 - .776 X' + 𝜀 This new regression equation shows the exact same relationship between Y and X' as we found for Y and X. If you calculate the error of this regression model, you will get the exact same SSEA Allows us to answer the following: Is a pattern evident in a set of data points? Which equation of a straight line can best describe this pattern? Are the predictions made from this equation significant? What is the nature of the relation between x and y.
Is b statistically significant? What is the Confidence Intervals (CI) for b?
What is the Effect Size ?
How is the y Variance partitioned between explained and unexplained?
Do plots of residuals indicate violations of assumptions for Bivariate Regression? Compact Model Total Error SST (total possible error = SSEC) Augmented Model Error in Model A SSEA (error of augmented model) SST - SSEa = Explained Error SSR = Compact Model - Augmented Model OR SSR = SSEC - SSEA
Effect Size R2 = (SSEC - SSEA) ÷ SSEC Football lovers will be more confident in their GLM statistics abilities. Hypothesis: Students who report higher levels of love for football will more likely report higher levels of GLM efficacy. Y: Student Engagement X: Teacher Enthusiasm Yi (Engagement) = 𝛽0 (Intercept) + 𝛽1 (Slope) Xi (Enthusiasm) + 𝜀i (Residual)

Count the number of parameters estimated by each model. Calculate the regression equation. Compute the total sum of squares (SSEC). Compute the sum of squares for Model A (SSEA). Compute sum of squares reduced (SSR). Compute the proportional reduction in error (PRE or R2). Complete the summary table. Decide about H0. Assumption of Linearity - Scatterplot - ANOVA table (deviation from linearity significance test, we want the value to NOT be linear)

university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
Going to have question about Dont forget to mention holding X For every 1 unit increase in X1 , when holding X2 constant. The first coding scheme that we will use is contrast coding. Using contrast codes For 2-category (binary) variable, one group is coded +1 and another group is coded -1 typically. Depressed are coded +1 and No Diagnoses is coded -1 The advantage of using the contrast codes is when the groups have equal N, the numerical values assigned to each group will sum to zero. By doing so, the intercept coefficient represents the grand mean and the slope coefficient represents the difference between the grand mean and each group. The estimated intercept coefficient (𝛽0) is the grand mean of outcome, Depression symptom score We will use the previous example with depression score as an outcome and the diagnosis variable as a predictor. Depression = 𝛽0 + 𝛽1Diagnosis + 𝜀 Using Contrast Codes For 2-category (binary) variable, one group is coded +1 and another group is coded -1 typically. Depressed are coded +1 and No Diagnosis coded -1. By doing so, the intercept coefficient represents the grand mean and the slope coefficient represents the difference between the grand mean and each group. The sum of the new Diagnosis variable is 0. The intercept coefficient represents the mean of outcome (Dependent, y) (Depression) when the predictor (Independent, x) (Diagnosis) is 0, meaning that it is the mean for all subjects (grand mean). Predictor and Outcome The slope coefficient represents the difference between the grand mean and the assigned group.
Regression model: Depression = 𝛽0 + 𝛽1Diagnosis + 𝜀 13 (grand mean) + 6.5 (Difference between the grand mean and each group) x Diagnosis + 𝜀 Using Dummy Codes For 2-category (binary) variable, one group is coded 0 and another group is coded 1. Depressed are coded 1 and No. Diagnosis coded 0. The advantage of using the dummy codes is that it is very simple; only 0 and 1 are used. You choose a reference group to compare with other groups. By doing so, the intercept coefficient represents the mean for the 0 group (No Diagnosis) and the slope coefficient represents the difference between the reference group (coded as 0) and the comparison group (Depressed). Depressed are coded 1 and No Diagnosis coded 0. The intercept coefficient represents the mean of outcome (Depression) when the predict 2r (Diagnosis) is 0, meaning that it is the mean for No Diagnosis group. The slope coefficient represents the difference between the reference group (coded as 0) and the comparison group (coded as 1).

Regression Model: Depression = 𝛽0 + 𝛽1Diagnosis + 𝜀 6.5 (mean for the 0 group) + 13 (difference between the reference group [coded as 0] and the comparison group [depressed]) x Diagnosis + 𝜀 We will expand our statistical models by adding more predictors to explain the outcome variable. From the previous augmented model (Model A) with a single predictor X, we will now have two predictors (X1 and X2) in Model A. This model comparison tests whether a model with two predictors (X1 and X2) is better than a model that just predicts the mean for every person. H0: 𝛽1 = 𝛽2 = 0 If the null hypothesis is not rejected, neither X1 nor X2 are related to Y. The multiple regression model is called the 'omnibus model' given that both regression coefficients of 𝛽1 and 𝛽2 are simultaneously estimated and tested. We will use the same example data for Y and X1 from the bivariate regression to analyze the multiple regression model with the new variable X2. State the compact Model C and an augmented Model A. Identify the null hypothesis (H0). Count the number of parameters estimated by each model. Calculate the regression equation. Compute the total sum of squares (SSEC). Compute the sum of squares for Model A (SSEA). Compute sum of squares reduced (SSR). Compute the proportional reduction in error (PRE or R2). Complete the summary table. Decide about H0. We use the data to estimate the regression equation for the omnibus Model A (Step 4). With bivariate regression, we easily calculated the regression coefficients (b0 and b1) by hand. We are not so lucky with multiple regression - or maybe we are very lucky, depending on your perspective. Although we could not compute the equation by hand, the formula consumes pages and would probably take an entire semester to calculate by hand (although admittedly I have only seen this equation once, during graduate school, and I have never tried to calculate a multiple regression by hand). university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: General Linear Model (GLM)
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description: The GLM is a basic framework underlying many statistical analyses. It is often expressed in a regression-type formula in which the expected value of a random dependent variable is given as a function of independent variables. The general linear model (GLM) is a way to simplify and combine multiple linear regression models into a single, unified format. It is not a different type of model but a more efficient way to represent them. General form: Y = XB + U Data = Model + Error The key word is 'general.' The GLM can be used to make predictions from various models. Depending on the outcome variable, logistic regression, ordinal regression, or count models (Poisson) may be used - these are also forms of the GLM. Another term: Generalized Linear Models (GLIM) The GLM is actually a special case of (GLIM)! Multivariate Model

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: Standard Deviation (SD)
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
A measure of the spread in a distribution derived from the sum of squared deviations from the mean of the distribution divided by the number of cases in the distribution. Since variance is a squared value, it is difficult to interpret. The standard deviation (SD) is the square root of the variance, and it is the most common measure of dispersion. For population: 𝜎 = square root of 𝜎2 For sample: 𝜎 = square root of 𝜎2 Measured on the same scale as original data. Interpretation: On average, the deviations from the mean, but on average the distance from the mean is about 2.92. The 68-95-99.7 rule (more next time): About 68% of data points fall within +/- 1 standard deviation from the mean. About 95% of data points fall within +/- 2 standard deviations from the mean. About 99.7% of data points fall within +/- 3 standard deviations from the mean. Excel Formula
Calculate the Mean =AVERAGE (First cell, Last cell) Calculate the Deviation = Data cell - Mean cell Square the Deviation =E 2^2
Calculate the Sum of Squares of Error (SSE) (Square Deviations) =SUM (First cell, Last cell) Input the Degrees of Freedom DF = n - 1 Calculate the Variance =SS / DF Calculate the Standard Deviation √(Variance) =SQRT (Cell) Calculate the Standard Error = Standard Deviation / √(n) =F 21 / (SQRT (15))

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: Variance
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description: If we square the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) between x and y, r2 indicates the proportion of the Variance in y that can be explained by x. The 'average' squared deviation from the mean for a set of scores. Variance is a better measure of dispersion than range and IQR, because it takes into account all the values for a set of scores (but might be affected by extreme values). Conceptually, the variance is a measure of the area of the distribution (i.e., the more spread out the scores, the more area or space the distribution takes up). The sample mean might not be the same as the population mean (usually unknown), and the deviations would be affected. Therefore, sample variance obtained would be systematically too small. In order to get an unbiased sample estimate of the population variance, a slight change in the computational formula was made. AKA Degree of Freedom (df) When we calculate a simple statistic based in part on another statistic, we have to consider the 'degrees of freedom' in our calculation. Given the sample mean, we do not need raw data from all n observations. We only need (n-1) observations, because the last missing score can be found from the mean (i.e., there is no 'freedom' in what this score might be). The denominator (n-1) in sample variance is called the degrees of freedom (df), which is related to sample size.

university-resources/statistics-classes/.title: GLM Quizzes
university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
The criterion or level of significance in behavioral research is typically set at what probability value? 0.05 or 5% The likelihood that we reject the null hypothesis decreases the closer the value of a sample mean is to the value stated by the null hypothesis. In hypothesis testing, a researcher's decision is based on a probability, depends on the level of significance for a hypothesis test, and can be to retain or reject the null hypothesis. Hypothesis testing is also called significance testing. The criteria for a decision regarding the value stated in a null hypothesis is set by the level of significance. In hypothesis testing, a researcher can never prove that their hypothesis is correct. In Step 2 of hypothesis testing, researchers state a level of significance to minimize the probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis. The power of the decision-making process is the likelihood of rejecting a false null hypothesis. Effect Size allows researchers to describe a.) how far mean scores have shifted in the population or b.) the percentage of variance that can be explained by a given variable. A researcher reports that the size of an effect in some population is d = .88. What is an appropriate interpretation? Mean scores shifted .88 standard deviations in the population Increasing sample size will increase the power of the decision. The t-distribution is similar to the z-distribution except it is associated with greater variability, 'thicker' tails compared with the z-distribution, and is associated with scores being more likely in the tails of the distribution. Key difference between t-statistic and z-statistic is the standard error is estimated to compute a t-statistic. Assumption for computing any type of independent sample t-test Data in the population being sampled are normally distributed (Assumption of )
Data were obtained from a sample that was selected using a random sampling procedure
The probabilities of each measured outcome in a study are independent As a requirement for the t-test, researchers compute any type of t-test with samples selected from populations in which the population variance is unknown. To compute a sample t-test, a researcher must known the estimated standard error, sample size, sample mean, and sample variance. Matched Samples Design is a research design in which two or more groups of individuals are identical, or matching, in terms of the third variable. Repeated Measures Design is an experiment using a within-group design in which participants respond to a dependent variable more than once, after exposure to each level of the independent variable. What is the denominator of the test statistic for the related samples t-test? Estimated standard error for difference scores All other things being equal, as the degrees of freedom increase, what happens to the critical value for a related-samples t-test? The critical value decreases

university-resources/statistics-classes/.description:
How to read description of a study and identify/infer relevant information such as: Independent Variable and Dependent Variable
Types of Variables
Sample Size
Number of groups for any Nominal Variable and Sample Size for each group
Number of Parameter s A description may or may not include all of the information above. How to look up the F-critical value and determine whether a model is significant How to look up the t-critical value & determine whether the t-test is significant How to run a t-test in SPSS
T-Test Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-sample t-test Pick variable and enter the Test Value (µ0) SPSS reports p-values for both one-sided (directional) and two-sided (non-directional) tests. However, confidence interval (CI) of mean difference is only constructed for two-sided.
Set up hypotheses based on the research question. Where does the sample/observed mean lie on the sampling distribution? Given the confidence level 100 (1 - 𝜎)%, what is considered extreme evidence? Compared to the critical value, is the sample mean extreme enough to be considered different from µ0? How to write a regression equation
Stating the Null Hypothesis and Alternative hypotheses The one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) is used to determine whether there are any statistically significant differences between the means of three or more independent (unrelated) groups.
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) The one-way ANOVA compares the means between the groups you are interested in and determines whether any of those means are statistically significantly different from each other. Specifically, it tests the null hypothesis:
Where µ = group mean and k = number of groups. If, however, the one-way ANOVA returns a statistically significant result, we accept the alternative hypothesis, which is that there are at least two group means that are statistically significantly different from each other. The one-way ANOVA is an Omnibus test statistic, and cannot tell you which specific groups were statistically significantly different from each other, only that at least two groups were. To determine which specific groups differed from each other, you need to use a post hoc test. It is used to test research questions and hypotheses where you want to compare the means of three or more groups on a single dependent variable. You are asking if there is a significant difference between the groups based on a single categorical independent variable with multiple levels.

If you are dealing with individuals, you are likely to encounter this situation using two different types of study design: One study design is to recruit a group of individuals and then randomly split this group into three or more smaller groups (i.e., each participant is allocated to one, and only one, group). You then get each group to undertake different tests (or put them under different conditions) and measure the outcome/response on the same dependent variable. For example, a researcher wishes to know whether different pacing strategies affect the time to complete a marathon. The researcher randomly assigns a group of volunteers to either a group that (a) starts slow and then increases their speed, (b) starts fast and slows down or (c) runs at a steady pace throughout. The time to complete the marathon is the outcome (dependent) variable.
A second study design is to recruit a group of individuals and then split them into groups based on some independent variable. Again, each individual will be assigned to one group only. This independent variable is sometimes called an attribute independent variable because you are splitting the group based on some attribute that they possess (e.g., their level of education; every individual has a level of education, even if it is 'none'). Each group is then measured on the same dependent variable having undergone the same task or condition (or none at all). For example, a researcher is interested in determining whether there are differences in leg strength between amateur, semi-professional and provessional rugby players. The force/strength measured on an isokinetic machine is the dependent variable.

Every time you conduct a t-test there is a chance that you will make a Type I Errors. This error is usually 5%. By running two t-tests on the same data you will have increased your chance of "making a mistake" to 10%. The formula for determining the new error rate for multiple t-tests is not as simple as multiplying 5% by the number of tests. However, if you are only making a few multiple comparisons, the results are very similar if you do. As such, three t-tests would be 15% (actually, 14.3%) and so on. These are unacceptable errors. An ANOVA controls for these errors so that the Type I Errors remains at 5% and you can be more confident that any statistically significant result you find is not just running lots of tests. State H0 and H1
H1: At least 1 group mean is different Set the criteria for a decision. State Alpha Level = .05 Compute the test statistic. Make a decision. When you choose to analyze your data using a one-way ANOVA, part of the process involves checking to make sure that the data you want to analyze can actually be analyzed using a one-way ANOVA. You need to do this because it is only appropriate to use a one-way ANOVA if your data "passes" six assumptions that are required for a one-way ANOVA to give you a valid result.
Your dependent variable should be measured at the interval or ratio level (Interval Variable and Ratio Variable) (i.e., they are Continuous Variable; IQ score, exam scores, weight, etc). The dependent variable is normally distributed in each group that is being compared in the one-way ANOVA (technically, it is the residuals that need to be normally distributed, but the results will be the same).
For example, if we were comparing three groups (e.g., amateur, semi-professional, and professional rugby players) on their leg strength, their leg strength values (Dependent Variable) would have to be normally distributed for the amateur group of players, normally distributed for the semi-professionals and normally distributed for the professional player. You can test for normality in SPSS.
Testing for Normality
Your Independent Variable is Nominal Variable. There is homogeneity of variances. This means that the population variances in each group are equal. If you use SPSS Statistics, Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variances is included in the output when you run a one-way ANOVA in SPSS Statistics. SPSS: Make sure to select the option of 'homogeneity of variance test.' The assumption of the homogeneity of the variance is met if Levene's statistic is not significant (p > .05)
Independence of Observations. This is mostly a study design issue and, as such, you will need to determine whether you believe it is possible that your observations are not independent based on your study design.
Your Independent Variable should consist of two or more categorical, independent groups. Typically, a one-way ANOVA is used when you have three or more categorical, independent groups, but it can be used for just two groups (but an Independent Samples T-Test Independent Samples T-Test is more commonly used for two groups) Example independent variables that meet this criterion include ethnicity (e.g., 3 groups: Caucasian, African American, and Hispanic), physical activity level (e.g., 4 groups: sedentary, low, moderate, and high), profession (e.g., 5 groups: surgeon, doctor, nurse, dentist, therapist) and so forth.
You should have Independence of Observations, which means that there is no relationship between the observations in each group or between the groups themselves. For example, there must be different participants in each group with no participant being in more than one group. This is more of a study design issue than something you can test for. If your study fails this assumption, you will need to use another statistical test instead of the one-way ANOVA (e.g., a repeated measures design).
If you are unsure whether your study meets this assumption, use Features - Statistical Test Selector | Laerd Statistics. There should be no significant outliers. Outliers are simply data points within your data that do not follow the usual pattern (e.g., in a study of 100 students' IQ scores, where the mean score was 108 with only a small variation between students, one student had a score of 156, which is very unusual, and may even put her in the top 1% of IQ scores globally). The problem with outliers is that they can have a negative effect on the one-way ANOVA, reducing the validity of your results.
Your Dependent Variable should be approximately normally distributed for each category of the Independent Variable. We talk about the one-way ANOVA only requiring approximately normal data because it is quite 'robust' to violations of normality, meaning that assumption can be a little violated and still provide valid results. You can test for normality using the Shapiro-Wilk test of normality, which is easily tested for using SPSS Statistics.


There needs to be Homogeneity of Variances. You can test this assumption in SPSS Statistics using Levene's test for homogeneity of variances. If your data fails this assumption, you will need to not only carry out a Welch ANOVA instead of a one-way ANOVA, which you can do using SPSS Statistics, but also use a different post hoc test. Levene's test tells us if we have met the assumption that the two groups have approximately equal variances on the dependent variable. If Levene's Test is significant ('Sig.' is less than .05), the two variances are significantly different. If Levene's Test is not significant, then the two variances are approximately equal, and the assumption is met.
The one-way ANOVA is considered a robust test against the normality assumption. This means that it tolerates violations to its normality assumption rather well. As regards the normality of group data, the one-way ANOVA can tolerate data that is non-normal (skewed or kurtotic distributions) with only a small effect on the Type I Errors rate. However, platykurtosis can have a profound effect when your group sizes are small. This leaves you with two options: Transform your data using various algorithms so that the shape of your distributions become normally distributed Choose the nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis H Test which does not require the assumption of normality. There are two tests that you can run that are applicable when the assumption of homogeneity of variances has been violated. Welch Brown and Forsythe test. Alternatively, you can run a Kruskal-Wallis H Test. For most situations, it has been shown that the Welch test is the best. Both the Welch and Brown and Forsythe tests are available in SPSS. A lack of independence of cases has been stated as the most serious assumptions to fail. Often, there is little you can do that offers a good solution to this problem. Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-Way ANOVA

Add Dependent Variable to the Dependent List box, and add the Independent Variable to the Factor box. Click Options. Check the box for Means Plot, then click Continue. Click OK when finished.
The Dependent Variable. This is the variable whose means will be compared between the samples (groups). You may run multiple means comparisons simultaneously by selecting more than one dependent variable.
The Independent Variable. The categories (or groups) of the independent variable will define which samples will be compared. The independent variable must have at least two categories (groups), but usually has three or more groups when used in a One-Way ANOVA. Specify contrasts, or planned comparisons, to be conducted after the overall ANOVA test. When the initial F-test indicates that significant differences exist between group means, contrasts are useful for determining which specific means are significantly different when you have specific hypotheses that you wish to test. Contrasts are decided before analyzing the data (i.e., priori). Contrasts break down the variance into component parts. They may involve using weights, non-orthogonal comparisons, standard contrasts, and polynomial contrasts (trend analysis).
Request post hoc (also known as multiple comparisons) tests. Specific post hoc tests can be selected by checking the associated boxes.
When the initial F test indicates that significant differences exist between group means, post hoc tests are useful for determining which specific means are significantly different when you do not have specific hypotheses you wish to test. Post hoc tests compare each pair of means (like T-Test s), but unlike T-Test s, they correct the significance estimate to account for the multiple comparisons.
Multiple comparisons options that assume homogeneity of variance (each group has equal variance). By default, a 2-sided hypothesis test is selected. Alternatively, a directional, one-sided hypothesis can be specified if you choose to use a Dunnett post hoc test. Click the box next to Dunnett and then specify whether the Control Category is the Last or First group, numerically, of your grouping variable. In the Test area, click either < Control or > Control. The one-tailed options require that you specify whether you predict that the mean for the specified control group will be less than (> Control) or greater than (< Control) another group. Multiple comparisons options that do not assume equal variances. The desired cutoff for statistical significance. By default, significance is set to 0.05. Clicking Options will produce a window where you can specify which Statistics to include in the output (Descriptive, Fixed and Random Effects, Homogeneity of Variance Test, Brown-Forsythe, Welch), whether to include a Means Plot, and how the analysis will address Missing Values (i.e., Exclude cases analysis by analysis or Exclude cases listwise). Click Continue when you are finished making specifications.
You will have calculated the following results or obtained them from SPSS. N is the total number of subjects and k is the number of groups

"There was a statistically significant difference between groups as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 4.467, p = .021)." this is all you will need to write for the one-way ANOVA per se. However, you will probably also want to report means ± Standard Deviation (SD) s for your groups, as well as follow up a statistically significant result with a post hoc test. The general form of writing the result of a one-way ANOVA is as follow:
You should not report the result as 'Significant difference,' but instead report it as 'statistically significant difference.' this is because your decision as to whether the result is significant or not should not be based solely on your statistical test. Difference A one-way ANOVA was used to test for mean differences in science type depending on the intent to stay. It was predicted that there would be differences among the science types, though no specific group differences were made a priori. Assumptions of the one-way ANOVA were upheld. For example, data was generally normally distributed with histograms following a normal distribution curve and a significant Shapiro-Wilk’s test. Similarly, HOV was upheld via a significant F value (F (2, 27) = 4.467, p = .021). There was a statistically significant difference between groups as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 4.467, p = .021). No Difference A one-way ANOVA was used to test for mean differences in science type depending on the intent to stay. It was predicted that there would be differences among the science types, though no specific group differences were made a priori. Assumptions of the one-way ANOVA were upheld. For example, data was generally normally distributed with histograms following a normal distribution curve and a significant Shapiro-Wilk’s test. Similarly, HOV was upheld via a significant F value (F (1, 42) = .010, p = .086). The results of the omnibus test suggests that there not statistically significant mean level differences in science type depending on the intent to stay (F (1, 42) = .010, p = .086, R2 = .00). The small effect size suggests that 0% of the observed variance in the science type can be explained by the intent to stay. Report the result of the one-way ANOVA (e.g., 'There were no statistically significant differences between group means as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 1.397, p = .15). Running a post hoc test is usually not warranted and should not be carried out. You need to report your results. You then need to follow-up the one-way ANOVA by running a post hoc test. You need to perform the same procedures as above, but add into your results section that this assumption was violated and you needed to run a Welch F test. ANOVA test tells you whether you have an overall difference between your groups, but it does not tell you which specific groups differed - post hoc tests do. Because post hoc tests are run to confirm where the differences occurred between groups, they should only be run when you have a shown an overall statistically significant difference in group means (i.e., a statistically significant one-way ANOVA result). Post hoc tests attempt to control the experiment-wise error rate (usually alpha = 0.05) in the same manner that the one-way ANOVA is used instead of multiple t-tests. Post hoc tests are termed a posteriori tests; that is, performed after the event (the event in this case being a study). There are a great number of different post hoc tests that you can use. However, you should only run one post hoc test - do not run multiple post hoc tests. For a one-way ANOVA, you will probably find that just two tests need to be considered. If your data met the assumption of homogeneity of variances, use Tukey's honestly significant difference (HSD) post hoc test. Note that if you use SPSS Statistics, Tukey's HSD test is simply referred to as 'Tukey' in the post post hoc multiple comparisons dialogue box. If your data did not meet the homogeneity fo variances assumption, you should consider running the Games Howell post hoc test.
Your Dependent Variable should be measured on a continuous scale (i.e., it is either an Interval Variable or Ratio Variable). Examples of variables that meet this criterion include revision time (measured in hours), intelligence (measured using IQ score), exam performance (measured from 0 to 100), weight (measured in kg), and so forth.
If your Dependent Variable was measured on an ordinal scale, you will need to carry out ordinal regression rather than multiple regression. Examples of Ordinal Variables include Likert items (e.g., a 7-point scale from 'strongly agree' through to 'strongly disagree'), amongst other ways of ranking categories (e.g., a 3-point scale explaining how much a customer liked a product, ranging from 'Not very much' to 'Yes, a lot').
You have two or more Independent Variable s, which can be either Continuous Variable (i.e., an Interval Variable or Ratio Variable) or Nominal Variable (i.e., an Ordinal Variables or Nominal Variable)
Examples of Nominal Variable include gender (e.g., 2 groups: male and female), ethnicity (e.g., 3 groups: Caucasian, African American and Hispanic), physical activity level (e.g., 4 groups: sedentary, low, moderate, and high), profession (e.g., 5 groups: surgeon, doctor, nurse, dentist, therapist), and so forth.
You should have Independence of Observations (i.e., independence of residuals), which you can easily check using the Durbin-Watson statistic. Click Analyze > Regression > Linear
You will be presented with the Linear Regression dialogue box below:

Transfer the Dependent Variable into the Dependent box and the Independent Variable s into the Independent (s) box. Click on the Statistics button. You will be presented with the Linear Regression: Statistics dialogue box.
In addition to the options that are selected by default, select Confidence Intervals in the Regression Coefficients area leaving the Level(%) option at 95.

The R column represents the value of R, the multiple correlation coefficient. R can be considered to be one measure of the quality of the prediction of the dependent variable, in this case, VO2max. A value of 0.760, in this example, indicates a good level of prediction.
The R Square column represents the R2 value (also called the coefficient of determination), which is the proportion of variance in the Dependent Variable that can be explained by the Independent Variable s (technically, it is the proportion of variation accounted for by the regression model above and beyond the mean model). You can see from our value of 0.577 that our Independent Variable s explain 57.7% of the variability of our Dependent Variable, VO2max.

The F-ratio in the ANOVA table (see below) tests whether the overall regression model is a good fit for the data. The table shows that the Independent Variable s statistically significantly predict the Dependent Variable, F(4, 95) = 32.393, p < .001 (i.e., the regression model is a good fit for the data).
The general form of the equation to predict VO2max from age, weight, heart-rate, gender is: Predicted VO2max = 87.83 - (0.165 x age) - (0.385 x weight) - (0.118 x heart-rate) + (13.208 x gender)
Unstandardized coefficients indicate how much the Dependent Variable varies with an Independent Variable when all other independent variables are held constant. Consider the effect of age in this example. The unstandardized coefficient, B1, for age is equal to -0.165. This means that for each one year increase in age, there is a decrease in VO2max of 0.165 ml/min/kg. You can test for the statistical significance of each of the independent variables. This tests whether the unstandardized (or standardized) coefficients are equal to 0 in the population. If p < .05, you can conclude that the coefficients are statistically significantly different to 0. The t-value and corresponding p-value are located in the 't' and 'Sig.' columns, respectively.

You can see from the 'Sig.' column that all Independent Variable coefficients are statistically significantly different from 0. Although the intercept, B0, is tested for statistical significance. info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_siteName.description: The name of the vault / exported site

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
